**Kyiv** (also **Kiev** )^[\[a\]](#cite_note-11)^ is the capital and most populous [city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Ukraine "List of cities in Ukraine") of [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine"). It is in north-central Ukraine along the [Dnieper River](/wiki/Dnieper "Dnieper"). As of 1 January 2022, its population was 2,952,301,^[\[2\]](#cite_note-Number_of_present_population_of_Ukraine_1_January_2022-2)^ making Kyiv the [seventh-most populous](/wiki/List_of_European_cities_by_population_within_city_limits "List of European cities by population within city limits") city in Europe.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-12)^ Kyiv is an important industrial, scientific, educational, and cultural center in [Eastern Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe"). It is home to many [high-tech](/wiki/High_tech "High tech") industries, higher education institutions, and historical landmarks. The city has an extensive system of [public transport](/wiki/Transport_in_Kyiv "Transport in Kyiv") and infrastructure, including the [Kyiv Metro](/wiki/Kyiv_Metro "Kyiv Metro").{#cite_ref-12}

The city's name is said to derive from the name of [Kyi](/wiki/Kyi "Kyi"), one of its four legendary founders. During [its history](/wiki/History_of_Kyiv "History of Kyiv"), Kyiv, one of the oldest cities in Eastern Europe, passed through several stages of prominence and obscurity. The city probably existed as a commercial center as early as the 5th century. A [Slavic](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") settlement on the great trade route between [Scandinavia](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia") and [Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople"), Kyiv was a tributary of the [Khazars](/wiki/Khazars "Khazars"),^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^ until its capture by the [Varangians](/wiki/Varangians "Varangians") ([Vikings](/wiki/Vikings "Vikings")) in the mid-9th century. Under Varangian rule, the city became a capital of [Kievan Rus'](/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27 "Kievan Rus'"), the first [East Slavic](/wiki/East_Slavs "East Slavs") state. Completely [destroyed](/wiki/Siege_of_Kiev_(1240) "Siege of Kiev (1240)") during the [Mongol invasions](/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Kievan_Rus%27 "Mongol invasion of Kievan Rus'") in 1240, the city lost most of its influence for the centuries to come. Coming under [Lithuania](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania "Grand Duchy of Lithuania"), then [Poland](/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland "Crown of the Kingdom of Poland") and then [Russia](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), the city would grow from a frontier market into an important centre of Orthodox learning in the sixteenth century, and later of industry, commerce, and administration by the nineteenth.^[\[1\]](#cite_note-auto-1)^{#cite_ref-auto_1-1}

The city prospered again during the Russian Empire's [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution") in the late 19th century. In 1918, when the [Ukrainian People's Republic](/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic "Ukrainian People's Republic") declared independence from the [Russian Republic](/wiki/Russian_Republic "Russian Republic") after the [October Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution") there, Kyiv became its capital. From the end of the [Ukrainian-Soviet](/wiki/Ukrainian-Soviet_war "Ukrainian-Soviet war") and [Polish-Soviet](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_war "Polish–Soviet war") wars in 1921, Kyiv was a city of the [Ukrainian SSR](/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic"), and made its capital in 1934. The city suffered significant destruction during [World War II](/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II) "Eastern Front (World War II)") but quickly recovered in the postwar years, remaining the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")'s third-largest city.

Following [the collapse of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union") and [Ukrainian independence](/wiki/Independence_of_Ukraine "Independence of Ukraine") in 1991, Kyiv remained Ukraine's capital and experienced a steady [influx](/wiki/Immigration_to_Ukraine "Immigration to Ukraine") of [ethnic Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainians "Ukrainians") migrants from other [regions of the country](/wiki/Regions_of_Ukraine "Regions of Ukraine").^[\[13\]](#cite_note-History_of_Ukraine-14)^ During the country's transformation to a [market economy](/wiki/Market_economy "Market economy") and [electoral democracy](/wiki/Representative_democracy "Representative democracy"), Kyiv has continued to be Ukraine's largest and wealthiest city. Its armament-dependent industrial output fell after the Soviet collapse, adversely affecting science and technology, but new sectors of the economy such as services and [finance](/wiki/Finance "Finance") facilitated Kyiv's growth in salaries and investment, as well as providing continuous funding for the development of [housing](/wiki/Housing "Housing") and urban infrastructure. Kyiv emerged as the most [pro-Western](/wiki/Pro-Western "Pro-Western") region of Ukraine; [parties](/wiki/Political_parties_in_Ukraine "Political parties in Ukraine") advocating tighter [integration with the European Union](/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_relations "Ukraine–European Union relations") dominate during [elections](/wiki/Elections_in_Ukraine "Elections in Ukraine").{#cite_ref-History_of_Ukraine_14-0}  

Name {#Name}
------------

See also: [Names of Kyiv](/wiki/Names_of_Kyiv "Names of Kyiv")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Polonia_Et_Ungaria_XX_Nova_Tabula%2C_detail_of_Kyiv_episcopate_%28%E2%80%9CKyouia_epatus%E2%80%9D%29.jpg/260px-Polonia_Et_Ungaria_XX_Nova_Tabula%2C_detail_of_Kyiv_episcopate_%28%E2%80%9CKyouia_epatus%E2%80%9D%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Polonia_Et_Ungaria_XX_Nova_Tabula,_detail_of_Kyiv_episcopate_(%E2%80%9CKyouia_epatus%E2%80%9D).jpg) Detail of Sebastian Münster's *[Map of Poland and Hungary](/wiki/File:Polonia_Et_Ungaria_XX_Nova_Tabula.jpg "File:Polonia Et Ungaria XX Nova Tabula.jpg")* , 1552, showing Kyiv labelled "Kyouia ep*iscop*atus" ("Kyiv episcopate")

* English: Kyiv ([/ˈkiːɪv/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*KEE-iv*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"),^[\[14\]](#cite_note-15)^ [/kiːv/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*KEEV*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^) or Kiev ([/ˈkiːɛv/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*KEE-ev*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"))^[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-lpd3-18)^{#cite_ref-lpd3_18-0}
* [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language"): Київ, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian "Romanization of Ukrainian"): *Kyiv*, pronounced [\[ˈkɪjiu̯\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Ukrainian "Help:IPA/Ukrainian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/1/13/Uk-%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.ogg/Uk-%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Uk-%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.ogg "File:Uk-Київ.ogg")^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^{#cite_ref-19}
* [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): Киев, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian "Romanization of Russian"): *Kiyev*,^[\[b\]](#cite_note-20)^ pronounced [\[ˈkʲi(j)ɪf\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian "Help:IPA/Russian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/69/Ru-%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2.ogg/Ru-%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Ru-%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2.ogg "File:Ru-Киев.ogg")^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-lpd3-18)^{#cite_ref-lpd3_18-1}

The traditional etymology, stemming from the *[Primary Chronicle](/wiki/Primary_Chronicle "Primary Chronicle")* , is that the name is a derivation of [Kyi](/wiki/Kyi,_Shchek_and_Khoryv "Kyi, Shchek and Khoryv") (Ukrainian: Кий, Russian: Кий,^[\[c\]](#cite_note-21)^ [rom.](/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian "Romanization of Russian"): *Ky* or *Kiy* ), the legendary eponymous founder of the city. According to [Oleg Trubachyov](/wiki/Oleg_Trubachyov "Oleg Trubachyov")'s etymological dictionary from the [Old East Slavic](/wiki/Old_East_Slavic_language "Old East Slavic language") name *\*Kyjevŭ gordŭ* (literally, "Kyi's castle", "Kyi's [gord](/wiki/Gord_(archaeology) "Gord (archaeology)")"), from [Proto-Slavic](/wiki/Proto-Slavic "Proto-Slavic") *\*kyjevъ* ,^[\[19\]](#cite_note-22)^ This etymology has been questioned, for instance by [Mykhailo Hrushevsky](/wiki/Mykhailo_Hrushevsky "Mykhailo Hrushevsky") who called it an "etymological myth", and meant that the names of the legendary founders are in turn based on place names. According to the Canadian Ukrainian linguist [Jaroslav Rudnyckyj](/wiki/Jaroslav_Rudnyckyj "Jaroslav Rudnyckyj"), the name can be connected to the Proto-Slavic root [\*kyjь](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/kyj%D1%8C "wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/kyjь"), but should be interpreted as meaning 'stick, pole' as in its modern Ukrainian equivalent [Кий](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9#Ukrainian "wikt:кий"). The name should in that case be interpreted as 'palisaded settlement'.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-23)^{#cite_ref-23}

*Kyiv* is the romanized official Ukrainian name for the city,^[\[21\]](#cite_note-collins-24)^^[\[22\]](#cite_note-25)^ and it is used for legislative and official acts.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-:1-26)^ *Kiev* is the traditional English name for the city,^[\[21\]](#cite_note-collins-24)^^[\[24\]](#cite_note-27)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-28)^ but because of its historical derivation from the Russian name, *Kiev* lost favor with many Western media outlets after the outbreak of the [Russo-Ukrainian War](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War") in 2014 in conjunction with the [KyivNotKiev](/wiki/KyivNotKiev "KyivNotKiev") campaign launched by Ukraine to change the way that international media were spelling the city's name.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-29)^{#cite_ref-29}  

History {#History}
------------------

Main article: [History of Kyiv](/wiki/History_of_Kyiv "History of Kyiv")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Kyiv](/wiki/Timeline_of_Kyiv "Timeline of Kyiv").  
See also: [Principality of Kiev](/wiki/Principality_of_Kiev "Principality of Kiev") and [Grand Prince of Kiev](/wiki/Grand_Prince_of_Kiev "Grand Prince of Kiev")

The first known humans in the region of Kyiv lived there in the late [paleolithic period](/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic "Upper Paleolithic") ([Stone Age](/wiki/Stone_Age "Stone Age")).^[\[27\]](#cite_note-use-30)^ The population around Kyiv during the [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age") formed part of the so-called [Trypillian culture](/wiki/Cucuteni%E2%80%93Trypillia_culture "Cucuteni–Trypillia culture"), as evidenced by artifacts from that culture found in the area.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-31)^ During the early [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") certain tribes settled around Kyiv that practiced land cultivation, husbandry and trading with the [Scythians](/wiki/Scythians "Scythians") and ancient states of the northern Black Sea coast.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-use-30)^ Findings of Roman coins of the 2nd to the 4th centuries suggest trade relations with the eastern provinces of the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-use-30)^ Notable archaeologists of the area around Kyiv include [Vikentiy Khvoyka](/wiki/Vikentiy_Khvoyka "Vikentiy Khvoyka").{#cite_ref-use_30-2}  

### Founding {#Founding}

Scholars continue to debate when the city was founded: The traditional founding date is 482 CE, so the city celebrated [its 1,500th anniversary](/wiki/1500th_anniversary_of_Kyiv "1500th anniversary of Kyiv") in 1982. Archaeological data indicates a founding in the sixth or seventh centuries,^[\[29\]](#cite_note-eob-32)^^[\[30\]](#cite_note-33)^ with some researchers dating the founding as late as the late 9th century.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-34)^{#cite_ref-34}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Kyi%2C_Czech%2C_Khoryv_and_Lubed_in_der_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82chronik.jpg/220px-Kyi%2C_Czech%2C_Khoryv_and_Lubed_in_der_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82chronik.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kyi,_Czech,_Khoryv_and_Lubed_in_der_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82chronik.jpg) Legendary [Kyi, Shchek, Khoryv and Lybid](/wiki/Kyi,_Shchek_and_Khoryv "Kyi, Shchek and Khoryv") in the [Radziwiłł Chronicle](/wiki/Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_Chronicle "Radziwiłł Chronicle")

There are several legendary accounts of the origin of the city. One tells of members of a Slavic tribe ([Eastern Polans](/wiki/Polans_(eastern) "Polans (eastern)")), brothers Kyi (the eldest, after whom the city was named), Shchek, Khoryv, and their sister Lybid, who founded the city (See the *[Primary Chronicle](/wiki/Primary_Chronicle "Primary Chronicle")* ).^[\[27\]](#cite_note-use-30)^ Another legend states that [Saint Andrew](/wiki/Saint_Andrew "Saint Andrew") passed through the area in the 1st century. Where the city is now he erected a cross, where a church later was built. Since the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages") an image of [Saint Michael](/wiki/Michael_(archangel) "Michael (archangel)") has represented the city as well as the [duchy](/wiki/Duchy_of_Kiev "Duchy of Kiev").{#cite_ref-use_30-3}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/P%C3%A1l_V%C3%A1g%C3%B3_%281853-1928%29_painter_The_Hungarian_at_Kiev_%281896-99%29.jpg/220px-P%C3%A1l_V%C3%A1g%C3%B3_%281853-1928%29_painter_The_Hungarian_at_Kiev_%281896-99%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:P%C3%A1l_V%C3%A1g%C3%B3_(1853-1928)_painter_The_Hungarian_at_Kiev_(1896-99).jpg) [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarians "Hungarians") at Kyiv in 830 during the times of the [Rus' Khaganate](/wiki/Rus%27_Khaganate "Rus' Khaganate"); painting by [Pál Vágó](/wiki/P%C3%A1l_V%C3%A1g%C3%B3 "Pál Vágó") (1853--1928)

There is little historical evidence pertaining to the period when the city was founded. Scattered [Slavic](/wiki/Slavic_peoples "Slavic peoples") settlements existed in the area from the 6th century, but it is unclear whether any of them later developed into the city. On the [Ptolemy world map](/wiki/Ptolemy%27s_world_map "Ptolemy's world map") there are several settlements indicated along the mid-stream of [Borysthenes](/wiki/Borysthenes "Borysthenes"), among which is Azagarium, which some historians believe to be the predecessor to Kyiv.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-35)^{#cite_ref-35}

However, according to the 1773 *Dictionary of Ancient Geography* of [Alexander Macbean](/wiki/Alexander_Macbean "Alexander Macbean"), that settlement corresponds to the modern city of [Chernobyl](/wiki/Chernobyl "Chernobyl"). Just south of Azagarium, there is another settlement, Amadoca, believed to be the capital of the Amadoci people^[\[33\]](#cite_note-36)^ living in an area between the marshes of Amadoca in the west and the Amadoca mountains in the east.{#cite_ref-36}

Another name for Kyiv mentioned in history, the origin of which is not completely clear, is Sambat, which apparently has something to do with the [Khazar Empire](/wiki/Khazar_Empire "Khazar Empire"). The *Primary Chronicle* says the residents of Kyiv told [Askold](/wiki/Askold_and_Dir "Askold and Dir") "there were three brothers Kyi, Shchek, and Khoriv. They founded this town and died, and now we are staying and paying taxes to their relatives the Khazars". In *De Administrando Imperio* , [Constantine Porphyrogenitus](/wiki/Constantine_Porphyrogenitus "Constantine Porphyrogenitus") mentions a caravan of small cargo boats which assembled annually, and writes, "They come down the river Dnieper and assemble at the strong-point of Kyiv (Kioava), also called Sambatas".^[\[34\]](#cite_note-37)^{#cite_ref-37}

At least three Arabic-speaking 10th century geographers who traveled the area mention the city of Zānbat as the chief city of the Russes. Among them are ibn Rustah, [Abu Sa'id Gardezi](/wiki/Abu_Sa%27id_Gardezi "Abu Sa'id Gardezi"), and an author of the [Hudud al-'Alam](/wiki/Hudud_al-%27Alam "Hudud al-'Alam"). The texts of those authors were discovered by Russian orientalist [Alexander Tumansky](/wiki/Alexander_Tumansky "Alexander Tumansky"). The etymology of Sambat has been argued by many historians, including [Grigoriy Ilyinsky](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%98%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9,_%D0%93%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%90%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87 "ru:Ильинский, Григорий Андреевич"), [Nikolay Karamzin](/wiki/Nikolay_Karamzin "Nikolay Karamzin"), [Jan Potocki](/wiki/Jan_Potocki "Jan Potocki"), [Nikolay Lambin](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9B%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BD,_%D0%9D%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87 "ru:Ламбин, Николай Петрович"), [Joachim Lelewel](/wiki/Joachim_Lelewel "Joachim Lelewel"), and [Guðbrandur Vigfússon](/wiki/Gu%C3%B0brandur_Vigf%C3%BAsson "Guðbrandur Vigfússon").

The Primary Chronicle states that at some point during the late 9th or early 10th century Askold and Dir, who may have been of Viking or Varangian descent, ruled in Kyiv. They were murdered by [Oleg of Novgorod](/wiki/Oleg_of_Novgorod "Oleg of Novgorod") in 882, but some historians, such as [Omeljan Pritsak](/wiki/Omeljan_Pritsak "Omeljan Pritsak") and [Constantine Zuckerman](/wiki/Constantine_Zuckerman "Constantine Zuckerman"), dispute that, arguing that Khazar rule continued as late as the 920s, leaving historical documents such as the [Kievan Letter](/wiki/Kievan_Letter "Kievan Letter") and [Schechter Letter](/wiki/Schechter_Letter "Schechter Letter").

Other historians suggest that [Magyar tribes](/wiki/Magyar_tribes "Magyar tribes") ruled the city between 840 and 878, before migrating with some [Khazar](/wiki/Khazars "Khazars") tribes to the [Carpathian Basin](/wiki/Carpathian_Basin "Carpathian Basin"). The Primary Chronicle mentions Hungarians passing near Kyiv. [Askold's Grave](/wiki/Askold%27s_Grave "Askold's Grave") was previously known as "[Uhorske urochyshche](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A3%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B5_%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%87%D0%B8%D1%89%D0%B5 "ru:Угорское урочище")" (Hungarian place).^[\[35\]](#cite_note-38)^{#cite_ref-38}

According to the aforementioned scholars the building of the fortress of Kyiv was finished in 840 under the leadership of Keő (Keve), Csák, and Geréb, three brothers, possibly members of the [Tarján tribe](/w/index.php?title=Tarj%C3%A1n_tribe&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tarján tribe (page does not exist)"). The three names appear in the Kyiv Chronicle as Kyi, Shchek, and Khoryv and may be not of Slavic origin, as Russian historians have always struggled to account for their meanings and origins. According to Hungarian historian Viktor Padányi, their names were inserted into the Kyiv Chronicle in the 12th century, and they were identified as old-Russian mythological heroes.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Lebedev_baptism.jpg/220px-Lebedev_baptism.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lebedev_baptism.jpg) *The Baptism of Kievans* , a painting by [Klavdiy Lebedev](/wiki/Klavdiy_Lebedev "Klavdiy Lebedev")

The city of Kyiv stood on the [trade route between the Varangians and the Greeks](/wiki/Trade_route_from_the_Varangians_to_the_Greeks "Trade route from the Varangians to the Greeks"). In 968 the nomadic [Pechenegs](/wiki/Pechenegs "Pechenegs") attacked and then [besieged the city](/wiki/Siege_of_Kiev_(968) "Siege of Kiev (968)").^[\[37\]](#cite_note-40)^ By 1000 CE the city had a population of 45,000.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}

In March 1169, Grand Prince [Andrey Bogolyubsky](/wiki/Andrey_Bogolyubsky "Andrey Bogolyubsky") of [Vladimir-Suzdal](/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal "Vladimir-Suzdal") [sacked Kyiv](/wiki/Sack_of_Kiev_(1169) "Sack of Kiev (1169)"), leaving the old town and the prince's hall in ruins.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-42)^^[\[40\]](#cite_note-43)^ He took many pieces of religious artwork - including the *[Theotokos of Vladimir](/wiki/Theotokos_of_Vladimir "Theotokos of Vladimir")* icon - from Vyshhorod.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-44)^ In 1203, Prince [Rurik Rostislavich](/wiki/Rurik_Rostislavich "Rurik Rostislavich") and his [Kipchak](/wiki/Kipchaks "Kipchaks") allies captured and burned Kyiv. In the 1230s, the city was besieged and ravaged several times by different Rus princes. The city had not recovered from these attacks when, in 1240, the [Mongol invasion of Rus'](/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Kievan_Rus%27 "Mongol invasion of Kievan Rus'"), led by [Batu Khan](/wiki/Batu_Khan "Batu Khan"), completed the [destruction of Kyiv](/wiki/Siege_of_Kyiv_(1240) "Siege of Kyiv (1240)").^[\[42\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}

These events had a profound effect on the future of the city and on the [East Slavic civilization](/wiki/Culture_of_ancient_Rus "Culture of ancient Rus"). Before Bogolyubsky's pillaging, Kyiv had had a reputation as one of the largest cities in the world, with a population exceeding 100,000 at the beginning of the 12th century.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}

In the early 1320s, a Lithuanian army led by Grand Duke [Gediminas](/wiki/Gediminas "Gediminas") defeated a Slavic army led by [Stanislav of Kyiv](/wiki/Stanislav_of_Kyiv "Stanislav of Kyiv") at the [Battle on the Irpen' River](/wiki/Battle_on_the_Irpen%27_River "Battle on the Irpen' River") and conquered the city. The [Tatars](/wiki/Tatars "Tatars"), who also claimed Kyiv, retaliated in 1324--1325, so while Kyiv was ruled by a Lithuanian prince, it had to pay tribute to the [Golden Horde](/wiki/Golden_Horde "Golden Horde"). Finally, as a result of the [Battle of Blue Waters](/wiki/Battle_of_Blue_Waters "Battle of Blue Waters") in 1362, [Algirdas](/wiki/Algirdas "Algirdas"), Grand Duke of Lithuania, incorporated Kyiv and surrounding areas into the [Grand Duchy of Lithuania](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania "Grand Duchy of Lithuania").^[\[44\]](#cite_note-47)^ In 1482, [Crimean Tatars](/wiki/Crimean_Tatars "Crimean Tatars") sacked and burned much of Kyiv.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-48)^ At the time of the Lithuanian rule, the core of the city was located in [Podil](/wiki/Podil "Podil") and there was a Lithuanian [Kyiv Castle](/w/index.php?title=Kyiv_Castle&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kyiv Castle (page does not exist)") \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BA "uk:Київський замок")\] with 18 towers on the [Zamkova Hora](/wiki/Zamkova_Hora_(Kyiv) "Zamkova Hora (Kyiv)") which served as a residence of [Vladimir Olgerdovich](/wiki/Vladimir_Olgerdovich "Vladimir Olgerdovich"), [Grand Prince of Kyiv](/wiki/Grand_Prince_of_Kiev "Grand Prince of Kiev"), and subsequently of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania (e.g. [Vytautas](/wiki/Vytautas "Vytautas")).^[\[46\]](#cite_note-49)^^[\[47\]](#cite_note-50)^{#cite_ref-50}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2.jpg) The 1686 city map of Kyiv ("Kiovia"), fortified [Podil](/wiki/Podil "Podil") with the "alten" city shown in ruins ("Rudera")

With the 1569 [Union of Lublin](/wiki/Union_of_Lublin "Union of Lublin"), when the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth") was established, the Lithuanian-controlled lands of the Kyiv region ([Podolia](/wiki/Podolia "Podolia"), [Volhynia](/wiki/Volhynia "Volhynia"), and [Podlachia](/wiki/Podlachia "Podlachia")) were transferred from the Grand Duchy of Lithuania to the [Crown of the Kingdom of Poland](/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland "Crown of the Kingdom of Poland"), and Kyiv became the capital of [Kyiv Voivodeship](/wiki/Kyiv_Voivodeship "Kyiv Voivodeship").^[\[48\]](#cite_note-51)^ The 1658 [Treaty of Hadiach](/wiki/Treaty_of_Hadiach "Treaty of Hadiach") envisaged Kyiv becoming the capital of the [Grand Duchy of Rus'](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Rus%27_(1658) "Grand Duchy of Rus' (1658)") within the [Polish--Lithuanian--Ruthenian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%E2%80%93Ruthenian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth"),^[\[49\]](#cite_note-52)^ but this provision of the treaty never went into operation.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}  

### Russian suzerainty {#Russian_suzerainty}

Occupied by Russian troops since the 1654 [Treaty of Pereyaslav](/wiki/Treaty_of_Pereyaslav "Treaty of Pereyaslav"), Kyiv became a part of the [Tsardom of Russia](/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia "Tsardom of Russia") from 1667 on the [Truce of Andrusovo](/wiki/Truce_of_Andrusovo "Truce of Andrusovo") and enjoyed a degree of autonomy. None of the Polish-Russian treaties concerning Kyiv have ever been ratified.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-54)^ In the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), Kyiv was a primary [Christian centre](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy "Eastern Orthodoxy"), attracting [pilgrims](/wiki/Pilgrim "Pilgrim"), and the cradle of many of the empire's most important religious figures, but until the 19th century, the city's commercial importance remained marginal.{#cite_ref-54}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Pic_I_V_Ivasiuk_Mykola_Bohdan_Khmelnytskys_Entry_to_Kyiv.jpg/220px-Pic_I_V_Ivasiuk_Mykola_Bohdan_Khmelnytskys_Entry_to_Kyiv.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pic_I_V_Ivasiuk_Mykola_Bohdan_Khmelnytskys_Entry_to_Kyiv.jpg) *The Entrance of [Bohdan Khmelnytsky](/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky "Bohdan Khmelnytsky") to Kyiv in 1649* by [Mykola Ivasyuk](/wiki/Mykola_Ivasyuk "Mykola Ivasyuk") (1865--1937) depicts events after the [Khmelnytsky Uprising](/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising "Khmelnytsky Uprising") against Polish domination.

In 1834, the Russian government established Saint Vladimir University, now called the [Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv](/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko_National_University_of_Kyiv "Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv") after the Ukrainian poet [Taras Shevchenko](/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko "Taras Shevchenko") (1814--1861). (Shevchenko worked as a field researcher and editor for the geography department). The medical faculty of Saint Vladimir University, separated into an independent institution in 1919--1921 during the Soviet period, became the [Bogomolets National Medical University](/wiki/Bogomolets_National_Medical_University "Bogomolets National Medical University") in 1995.

During the 18th and 19th centuries, the [Imperial Russian Army](/wiki/Imperial_Russian_Army "Imperial Russian Army") and ecclesiastical authorities dominated city life;^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ the [Russian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church "Russian Orthodox Church") had involvement in a significant part of Kyiv's infrastructure and commercial activity. In the late 1840s the historian, [Mykola Kostomarov](/wiki/Mykola_Kostomarov "Mykola Kostomarov") (Russian: *Nikolai Kostomarov*), founded a secret political society, the Brotherhood of [Saint Cyril](/wiki/Saints_Cyril_and_Methodius "Saints Cyril and Methodius") and Methodius, whose members put forward the idea of a federation of free [Slavic peoples](/wiki/Slavic_peoples "Slavic peoples") with Ukrainians as a distinct and separate group rather than a subordinate part of the Russian nation; the Russian authorities quickly suppressed the society.

Following the gradual loss of Ukraine's autonomy, Kyiv experienced growing [Russification](/wiki/Russification "Russification") in the 19th century, by means of Russian migration, administrative actions, and social modernization. At the beginning of the 20th century the [Russian-speaking](/wiki/Russian_language_in_Ukraine "Russian language in Ukraine") part of the population dominated the city centre, while the [lower classes](/wiki/Social_class "Social class") living on the outskirts retained Ukrainian [folk culture](/wiki/Folk_culture "Folk culture") to a significant extent.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ However, enthusiasts among ethnic Ukrainian aristocrats, soldiers, and merchants made attempts to preserve the native culture in Kyiv, by clandestine book-printing, amateur theatre, folk studies, etc.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Kiev_downtown.jpg/220px-Kiev_downtown.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kiev_downtown.jpg) Kyiv in the late 19th century

During the [Russian industrial revolution](/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_Russian_Empire "Industrialization in the Russian Empire") in the late 19th century, Kyiv became an important trade and transportation centre of the Russian Empire, specialising in sugar and grain export by railway and on the [Dnieper river](/wiki/Dnieper_river "Dnieper river"). By 1900, the city had also become a significant industrial centre, with a population of 250,000. Landmarks of that period include the railway infrastructure, the foundation of numerous educational and cultural facilities, and notable architectural monuments (mostly merchant-oriented). In 1892, the [first electric tram line](/wiki/Trams_in_Kyiv "Trams in Kyiv") of the Russian Empire started running in Kyiv (the third in the world). Kyiv prospered during the late 19th century [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution") in the Russian Empire, when it became the third most important city of the Empire and the major centre of commerce in its southwest.  

### Soviet era {#Soviet_era}

In the [turbulent period](/wiki/Ukraine_after_the_Russian_Revolution "Ukraine after the Russian Revolution") following the [1917 Russian Revolution](/wiki/Russian_Revolution_(1917) "Russian Revolution (1917)"), Kyiv became the capital of several [successive Ukrainian states](/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic "Ukrainian People's Republic") and was caught in the middle of several conflicts: [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), during which German soldiers occupied it from 2 March 1918 to November 1918, the [Russian Civil War](/wiki/Russian_Civil_War "Russian Civil War") of 1917 to 1922, and the [Polish--Soviet War](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War "Polish–Soviet War") of 1919--1921. During the last three months of 1919, Kyiv was intermittently controlled by the [White Army](/wiki/White_Army "White Army"). Kyiv changed hands sixteen times from the end of 1918 to August 1920.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-55)^{#cite_ref-55}

From 1921 to 1991, the city formed part of the [Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic"), which became a founding republic of the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") in 1922. The major events that took place in Soviet Ukraine during the [interwar period](/wiki/Interwar_period "Interwar period") all affected Kyiv: the 1920s [Ukrainization](/wiki/Ukrainization "Ukrainization") as well as the migration of the rural Ukrainophone population made the [Russophone](/wiki/Russophone "Russophone") city Ukrainian-speaking and bolstered the development of [Ukrainian cultural life](/wiki/Ukrainian_culture "Ukrainian culture") in the city; the [Soviet industrialization](/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_Soviet_Union "Industrialization in the Soviet Union") that started in the late 1920s turned the city, a former centre of commerce and religion, into a major industrial, technological and scientific centre; the [1932--1933 Great Famine](/wiki/Holodomor "Holodomor") devastated the part of the migrant population not registered for ration cards; and [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin")'s [Great Purge](/wiki/Great_Purge "Great Purge") of 1937--1938 almost eliminated the city's [intelligentsia](/wiki/Intelligentsia "Intelligentsia")^[\[53\]](#cite_note-Brama-56)^^[\[54\]](#cite_note-Figes-57)^^[\[55\]](#cite_note-Social_Catastrophe-58)^{#cite_ref-Social_Catastrophe_58-0}

In 1934, Kyiv became the capital of Soviet Ukraine. The city boomed again during the years of Soviet industrialization as its population grew rapidly and many industrial giants were established, some of which exist today.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%D0%93%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%94%D0%B2%D0%B0_1936.jpg/220px-%D0%93%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%94%D0%B2%D0%B0_1936.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%93%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%94%D0%B2%D0%B0_1936.jpg) Until 1936, Kyiv was a city on the west bank of the [Dnieper](/wiki/Dnieper "Dnieper") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg/220px-Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg) Ruins of Kyiv during [World War II](/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II) "Eastern Front (World War II)")

In [World War II](/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II) "Eastern Front (World War II)"), the city again suffered significant damage, and [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") occupied it from 19 September 1941 to [6 November 1943](/wiki/Battle_of_Kiev_(1943) "Battle of Kiev (1943)"). [Axis](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers") forces killed or captured more than 600,000 Soviet soldiers in the great encircling [Battle of Kyiv](/wiki/Battle_of_Kyiv_(1941) "Battle of Kyiv (1941)") in 1941. Most of those captured never returned alive.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-59)^ Shortly after the [Wehrmacht](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht") occupied the city, a team of [NKVD](/wiki/NKVD "NKVD") officers who had remained hidden dynamited most of the buildings on the [Khreshchatyk](/wiki/Khreshchatyk "Khreshchatyk"), the main street of the city, where German military and civil authorities had occupied most of the buildings; the buildings burned for days and 25,000 people were left homeless.{#cite_ref-59}

Allegedly in response to the actions of the NKVD, the Germans rounded up all the local [Jews](/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Ukraine "The Holocaust in Ukraine") they could find, nearly 34,000,^[\[57\]](#cite_note-60)^ and massacred them at [Babi Yar](/wiki/Babi_Yar "Babi Yar") in Kyiv on 29 and 30 September 1941.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-61)^ In the months that followed, thousands more were taken to Babi Yar where they were shot. It is estimated that the Germans murdered [more than 100,000 people](/wiki/List_of_victims_of_the_Babi_Yar_massacre "List of victims of the Babi Yar massacre") of various ethnic groups, mostly civilians, at Babi Yar during World War II.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-62)^{#cite_ref-62}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Kiev_24.7.1990_Ukrainian_Flag.JPG/170px-Kiev_24.7.1990_Ukrainian_Flag.JPG)](/wiki/File:Kiev_24.7.1990_Ukrainian_Flag.JPG) The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kyiv's City Hall for the first time on 24 July 1990.

Kyiv recovered economically in the post-war years, becoming once again the third-most important city of the Soviet Union. The [catastrophic accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant](/wiki/Chernobyl_disaster "Chernobyl disaster") in 1986 occurred only 100 km (62 mi) north of the city. However, the prevailing south wind blew most of the radioactive debris away from Kyiv.  

### Independence {#Independence}

In the course of the [collapse of the Soviet Union](/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1982%E2%80%931991) "History of the Soviet Union (1982–1991)") the [Ukrainian parliament](/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada "Verkhovna Rada") proclaimed the [Declaration of Independence of Ukraine](/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_of_Ukraine "Declaration of Independence of Ukraine") in the city on 24 August 1991. In 2004--2005, the city played host to the largest post-Soviet public demonstrations up to that time, in support of the [Orange Revolution](/wiki/Orange_Revolution "Orange Revolution"). From November 2013 until February 2014, central Kyiv became the primary location of [Euromaidan](/wiki/Euromaidan "Euromaidan"). During the onset of the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine") in February 2022, [Russian forces](/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces "Russian Armed Forces") attempted to [seize Kyiv](/wiki/Northern_front_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Northern front of the Russian invasion of Ukraine") but were [repelled](/wiki/Battle_of_Kyiv_(2022) "Battle of Kyiv (2022)") by [Ukrainian forces](/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine "Armed Forces of Ukraine") on the outskirts of the city; Kyiv itself escaped major damage. Following the Russian retreat from the region in April 2022, Kyiv has been subject to frequent [air strikes](/wiki/Kyiv_strikes_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Kyiv strikes (2022–present)").  

Environment {#Environment}
--------------------------

See also: [Kyiv Mountains](/wiki/Kyiv_Mountains "Kyiv Mountains")  

### Geography {#Geography}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Kyiv%2C_Ukraine_ESA22370890_%28cropped%29.jpeg/220px-Kyiv%2C_Ukraine_ESA22370890_%28cropped%29.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Kyiv,_Ukraine_ESA22370890_(cropped).jpeg) A [Copernicus Programme](/wiki/Copernicus_Programme "Copernicus Programme") [Sentinel-2](/wiki/Sentinel-2 "Sentinel-2") image of Kyiv and the [Dnieper](/wiki/Dnieper "Dnieper")

Geographically, Kyiv is on the border of the [Polesia](/wiki/Polesia "Polesia") woodland ecological zone, a part of the European mixed woods area, and the East European [forest steppe](/wiki/Forest_steppe "Forest steppe") [biome](/wiki/Biome "Biome"). However, the city's unique landscape distinguishes it from the surrounding region. Kyiv is completely surrounded by [Kyiv Oblast](/wiki/Kyiv_Oblast "Kyiv Oblast").

Originally on the west bank, today Kyiv is on both sides of the [Dnieper](/wiki/Dnieper "Dnieper"), which flows southwards through the city towards the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea"). The older and higher western part of the city sits on numerous wooded hills ([Kyiv Hills](/wiki/Kyiv_Mountains "Kyiv Mountains")), with ravines and small rivers. Kyiv's geographical relief contributed to its [toponyms](/wiki/Toponym "Toponym"), such as *Podil* ("lower"), *Pechersk* ("caves"), and *uzviz* (a steep street, "descent"). Kyiv is a part of the larger [Dnieper Upland](/wiki/Dnieper_Upland "Dnieper Upland") adjoining the western bank of the Dnieper in its mid-flow, and which contributes to the city's elevation change.

The northern outskirts of the city border the [Polesian Lowland](/wiki/Polesian_Lowland "Polesian Lowland"). Kyiv expanded into the [Dnieper Lowland](/wiki/Dnieper_Lowland "Dnieper Lowland") on the left bank (*to the east* ) as late as the 20th century. The whole portion of Kyiv on the left bank of the Dnieper is generally referred to as the *Left Bank* (Лівий берег, *Livyi bereh*). Significant areas of the left bank Dnieper valley were artificially sand-deposited, and are protected by dams.

Within the city the Dnieper River forms a branching system of [tributaries](/wiki/Tributary "Tributary"), isles, and harbors within the city limits. The city is close to the mouth of the [Desna River](/wiki/Desna_River "Desna River") and the [Kyiv Reservoir](/wiki/Kyiv_Reservoir "Kyiv Reservoir") in the north, and the [Kaniv Reservoir](/wiki/Kaniv_Reservoir "Kaniv Reservoir") in the south. Both the Dnieper and Desna rivers are [navigable](/wiki/Navigation "Navigation") at Kyiv, although regulated by the reservoir shipping locks and limited by winter freeze-over.

In total, there are 448 bodies of open water within the boundaries of Kyiv, which include the Dnieper itself, its reservoirs, and several small rivers, dozens of lakes and artificially created ponds. They occupy 7949 hectares. Additionally, the city has 16 developed beaches (totalling 140 hectares) and 35 near-water recreational areas (covering more than 1,000 hectares). Many are used for pleasure and recreation, although some of the bodies of water are not suitable for swimming.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-63)^^[\[61\]](#cite_note-64)^{#cite_ref-64}

According to the [UN](/wiki/UN "UN") 2011 evaluation, there were no risks of [natural disasters](/wiki/Natural_disaster "Natural disaster") in Kyiv and [its metropolitan area](/wiki/Kyiv_metropolitan_area "Kyiv metropolitan area").^[\[62\]](#cite_note-UN_Urban_agglomerations_types_of_natural_risks-65)^{#cite_ref-UN_Urban_agglomerations_types_of_natural_risks_65-0}  

### Climate {#Climate}

Kyiv has a warm-summer [humid continental](/wiki/Continental_climate "Continental climate") [climate](/wiki/Climate "Climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") *Dfb* ).^[\[63\]](#cite_note-66)^ The warmest months are June, July, and August, with mean temperatures of 13.8 to 24.8 °C (56.8 to 76.6 °F). The coldest are December, January, and February, with mean temperatures of −4.6 to −1.1 °C (23.7 to 30.0 °F). The highest ever temperature recorded in the city was 39.4 °C (102.9 °F) on 30 July 1936.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-extremes1-67)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-extremes2-68)^{#cite_ref-extremes2_68-0}

The coldest temperature ever recorded in the city was −32.9 °C (−27.2 °F) on 11 January 1951.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-extremes1-67)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-extremes2-68)^ Snow cover usually lies from mid-November to the end of March, with the frost-free period lasting 180 days on average, but surpassing 200 days in some years.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-eob-32)^{#cite_ref-eob_32-1}

Legal status, local government and politics {#Legal_status.2C_local_government_and_politics}
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Legal status and local government {#Legal_status_and_local_government}

Main article: [Legal status and local government of Kyiv](/wiki/Legal_status_and_local_government_of_Kyiv "Legal status and local government of Kyiv")

The municipality of the city of Kyiv has a [special legal status](/wiki/Cities_with_special_status "Cities with special status") within Ukraine compared to the other [administrative subdivisions of the country](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Ukraine "Administrative divisions of Ukraine"). The most significant difference is that the city is considered as a region of Ukraine (see [Regions of Ukraine](/wiki/Regions_of_Ukraine "Regions of Ukraine")). It is the only city that has double jurisdiction. The Head of [City State Administration](/wiki/Chief_of_Local_State_Administration_(Ukraine) "Chief of Local State Administration (Ukraine)") -- the city's governor -- is appointed by the [president of Ukraine](/wiki/President_of_Ukraine "President of Ukraine"), while the Head of the City Council -- the [mayor of Kyiv](/wiki/Mayor_of_Kyiv "Mayor of Kyiv") -- is elected by local popular vote.

The mayor of Kyiv is [Vitali Klitschko](/wiki/Vitali_Klitschko "Vitali Klitschko"), who was sworn in on 5 June 2014,^[\[4\]](#cite_note-KKMs5614-4)^ after he had won the [25 May 2014 Kyiv mayoral elections](/wiki/2014_Kyiv_local_election "2014 Kyiv local election") with almost 57% of the votes.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-votecountKMEIU4614-73)^ Since 25 June 2014, Klitschko is also [Head of Kyiv City Administration](/wiki/Kyiv_City_State_Administration "Kyiv City State Administration").^[\[5\]](#cite_note-Poroshenko_appoints_Klitschko_head_of_Kyiv_city_administration_-_decree-5)^ Klitschko was last reelected in the [2020 Kyiv local election](/wiki/2020_Kyiv_local_election "2020 Kyiv local election") with 50.52% of the votes, in the first round of the election.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-3131537KlitschkoRE-74)^{#cite_ref-3131537KlitschkoRE_74-0}

Most key buildings of the national government are along [Hrushevskoho Street](/wiki/Hrushevsky_Street_(Kyiv) "Hrushevsky Street (Kyiv)") (*vulytsia Mykhaila Hrushevskoho* ) and Institute Street (*vulytsia Instytutska* ). Hrushevskoho Street is named after the Ukrainian academician, politician, historian, and statesman [Mykhailo Hrushevsky](/wiki/Mykhailo_Hrushevsky "Mykhailo Hrushevsky"), who wrote an academic book titled: "Bar Starostvo: Historical Notes: XV--XVIII" about the history of [Bar, Ukraine](/wiki/Bar,_Ukraine "Bar, Ukraine").^[\[72\]](#cite_note-75)^ That portion of the city is also unofficially known as the government quarter (урядовий квартал).{#cite_ref-75}

The city state administration and council is in the Kyiv City council building on Khreshchatyk Street. The oblast state administration and council is in the oblast council building on *ploshcha Lesi Ukrainky* ("Lesya Ukrainka Square").

The growing political and economic role of the city, combined with its international relations, as well as extensive [internet and social network penetration](/wiki/Internet_in_Ukraine "Internet in Ukraine"),^[\[73\]](#cite_note-Siumar_on_Kyiv-76)^ have made Kyiv the most pro-Western and pro-democracy region of Ukraine; (so called) [National Democratic](/wiki/National_democratic "National democratic") [parties](/wiki/Political_parties_in_Ukraine "Political parties in Ukraine") advocating tighter [integration with the European Union](/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_relations "Ukraine–European Union relations") receive most votes during [elections](/wiki/Elections_in_Ukraine "Elections in Ukraine") in Kyiv.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-radiosvoboda.org-77)^^[\[75\]](#cite_note-Битва_за_Київ-78)^^[\[76\]](#cite_note-Nebozhenko-79)^^[\[77\]](#cite_note-pravda1629-80)^ In a poll conducted by the [Kyiv International Institute of Sociology](/wiki/Kyiv_International_Institute_of_Sociology "Kyiv International Institute of Sociology") in the first half of February 2014, 5.3% of those polled in Kyiv believed "Ukraine and Russia must unite into a single state", nationwide this percentage was 12.5.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-81)^{#cite_ref-81}

#### Traditional subdivision {#Traditional_subdivision}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/2018-07-15_Dniprovska_Embankment%2C_Berezniaky%2C_Kyiv_2.jpg/220px-2018-07-15_Dniprovska_Embankment%2C_Berezniaky%2C_Kyiv_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018-07-15_Dniprovska_Embankment,_Berezniaky,_Kyiv_2.jpg) The Berezniaky neighbourhood in [Dniprovskyi District](/wiki/Dniprovskyi_District,_Kyiv "Dniprovskyi District, Kyiv")

The [Dnieper River](/wiki/Dnieper_River "Dnieper River") naturally divides Kyiv into the Right Bank and the Left Bank areas. Historically on the western right bank of the river, the city expanded into the left bank only in the 20th century. Most of Kyiv's attractions as well as the majority of business and governmental institutions are on the right bank. The eastern "Left Bank" is predominantly residential. There are large industrial and green areas in both the Right Bank and the Left Bank.

Kyiv is further informally divided into historical or territorial neighbourhoods, each housing from about 5,000 to 100,000 inhabitants.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B0.jpg/1530px-%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B0.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B0.jpg "A panoramic view of Right-Bank Kyiv, where the city centre is located (May 2011)")

#### Formal subdivision {#Formal_subdivision}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/%D0%90%D0%B4%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B4%D1%96%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%94%D0%B2%D0%B0.gif/280px-%D0%90%D0%B4%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B4%D1%96%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%94%D0%B2%D0%B0.gif)](/wiki/File:%D0%90%D0%B4%D0%BC%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B4%D1%96%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%94%D0%B2%D0%B0.gif) The ten [districts (raions) of Kyiv](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Kyiv "Subdivisions of Kyiv"):  
* Г -- [Holosiivskyi District](/wiki/Holosiivskyi_District "Holosiivskyi District")
* О -- [Obolonskyi District](/wiki/Obolonskyi_District "Obolonskyi District")
* Печ -- [Pecherskyi District](/wiki/Pecherskyi_District "Pecherskyi District")
* Под -- [Podilskyi District](/wiki/Podilskyi_District "Podilskyi District")
* Ш -- [Shevchenkivskyi District](/wiki/Shevchenkivskyi_District,_Kyiv "Shevchenkivskyi District, Kyiv")
* Св -- [Sviatoshynskyi District](/wiki/Sviatoshynskyi_District "Sviatoshynskyi District")
* Сол -- [Solomianskyi District](/wiki/Solomianskyi_District "Solomianskyi District")
* Дар -- [Darnytskyi District](/wiki/Darnytskyi_District "Darnytskyi District")
* Дес -- [Desnianskyi District](/wiki/Desnianskyi_District,_Kyiv "Desnianskyi District, Kyiv")
* Дн -- [Dniprovskyi District](/wiki/Dniprovskyi_District,_Kyiv "Dniprovskyi District, Kyiv")

The first known formal subdivision of Kyiv dates to 1810 when the city was subdivided into 4 parts: [Pechersk](/wiki/Pechersk,_Kyiv "Pechersk, Kyiv"), Starokyiv, and the first and the second parts of [Podil](/wiki/Podil "Podil"). In 1833--1834 according to [Tsar](/wiki/Russian_tsar "Russian tsar") [Nicholas I](/wiki/Nicholas_I_of_Russia "Nicholas I of Russia")'s decree, Kyiv was subdivided into 6 police [raions](/wiki/Raion "Raion") ([districts](/wiki/Urban_districts_of_Ukraine "Urban districts of Ukraine")); later being increased to 10. In 1917, there were 8 Raion Councils (*Duma* ), which were reorganised by [bolsheviks](/wiki/Bolshevik "Bolshevik") into 6 Party-Territory Raions.

During the Soviet era, as the city was expanding, the number of raions also gradually increased. These newer districts of the city, along with some older areas were then named in honour of prominent communists and socialist-revolutionary figures; however, due to the way in which many communist party members eventually, after a certain period of time, fell out of favour and so were replaced with new, fresher minds, so too did the names of Kyiv's districts change accordingly.

The last district reform took place in 2001 when the number of districts was decreased from 14 to 10.

Under [Oleksandr Omelchenko](/wiki/Oleksandr_Omelchenko "Oleksandr Omelchenko") (mayor from 1999 to 2006), there were further plans for the merger of some districts and revision of their boundaries, and the total number of districts had been planned to be decreased from 10 to 7. With the election of the new mayor-elect ([Leonid Chernovetskyi](/wiki/Leonid_Chernovetskyi "Leonid Chernovetskyi")) in 2006, these plans were shelved.

Each district has its own [locally elected council](/wiki/Local_government "Local government") with jurisdiction over a limited scope of affairs.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-796003Kyivdistrictcouncils-82)^{#cite_ref-796003Kyivdistrictcouncils_82-0}

[Historical population]

According to the [All-Ukrainian Census](/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001) "Ukrainian Census (2001)"), the population of Kyiv in 2001 was 2,611,327.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-population-87)^ The historic changes in population are shown in the side table. According to the census, some 1,393,000 (53.3%) were female and 1,219,000 (46.7%) were male. Comparing the results with the previous census (1989) shows the trend of [population ageing](/wiki/Population_ageing "Population ageing") which, while prevalent throughout the country, is partly offset in Kyiv by the inflow of working age migrants. Some 1,069,700 people had higher or completed secondary education, a significant increase of 21.7% since 1989.{#cite_ref-population_87-0}

The June 2007 unofficial population estimate based on amount of [bakery](/wiki/Bakery "Bakery") products sold in the city (thus including temporary visitors and commuters) gave a number of at least 3.5 million people.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-undercounted_residents_in_Kiev-88)^{#cite_ref-undercounted_residents_in_Kiev_88-0}  

### Ethnic composition {#Ethnic_composition}

Kyiv's ethnic composition has shifted greatly over the last centuries. According to the [census of March 2, 1874](/w/index.php?title=1874_Kiev_city_census&action=edit&redlink=1 "1874 Kiev city census (page does not exist)") \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81_(1874) "uk:Київський одноденний перепис (1874)")\], conducted by the local branch of the [Russian Geographical Society](/wiki/Russian_Geographical_Society "Russian Geographical Society"), there were 127,205 people living in Kyiv. Of these, 80% spoke "[Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language")," 11% spoke "[Jewish](/wiki/Yiddish "Yiddish")," 6% spoke [Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language") and 2% spoke [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"). Of the "Russian" speakers, 39% were recorded as speaking Little Russian (Ukrainian), which meant that Ukrainian speakers accounted for 30% of the city as a whole. Of the remaining "Russian" speakers, however, there were only 10% who spoke Greater Russian ([Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language")) and 2% who spoke [Belarusian](/wiki/Belarusian_language "Belarusian language"). The remaining 49% spoke in "generally Russian speech."^[\[86\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHamm1993103-89)^ According to the official census of 1897, the number of Great Russian speakers rose to 54%; speakers of Little Russian accounted for 22%. Jewish speakers accounted for 12%, Polish 6.7%.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHamm1993103-104-90)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHamm1993103-104_90-0}

By the September 1917 city-census of Kyiv, conducted by the authorities of the [Ukrainian People's Republic](/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic "Ukrainian People's Republic"), the Ukrainian share of the population had been reduced to only 16%, while Russians now made up a majority at 50%. The [March 1919 Kyiv city census](/wiki/Kyiv_city_census_(1919) "Kyiv city census (1919)"), conducted by the Bolshevik authorities, showed an increase in the percentage of the population identifying as Ukrainian to 25%. From then on, the city's Ukrainian population once again began to expand in terms of their share of the population, slowly returning to its former level.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-91)^ By the [1926 Soviet census](/wiki/Soviet_Census_(1926) "Soviet Census (1926)"), Ukrainians, at 41.6%, had once again begun to outnumber Russians, who made up 25.5%. By the [1959 Soviet census](/wiki/Soviet_Census_(1959) "Soviet Census (1959)"), Kyiv was once more a Ukrainian majority city, with 60% of the population identifying as such, the same percentage as in 1874.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-92)^{#cite_ref-92}

According to the 2001 census data, more than 130 nationalities and ethnic groups reside within the territory of Kyiv. [Ukrainians](/wiki/Ukrainians "Ukrainians") constitute the largest [ethnic group](/wiki/Ethnic_group "Ethnic group") in Kyiv, accounting for 2,110,800 people, or 82.2% of the population. [Russians](/wiki/Russians "Russians") comprise 337,300 (13.1%), Jews 17,900 (0.7%), [Belarusians](/wiki/Belarusians "Belarusians") 16,500 (0.6%), [Poles](/wiki/Polish_people "Polish people") 6,900 (0.3%), [Armenians](/wiki/Armenians "Armenians") 4,900 (0.2%), [Azerbaijanis](/wiki/Azerbaijani_people "Azerbaijani people") 2,600 (0.1%), Tatars 2,500 (0.1%), [Georgians](/wiki/Georgians "Georgians") 2,400 (0.1%), [Moldovans](/wiki/Moldovans "Moldovans") 1,900 (0.1%).^[\[90\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}

A 2015 study by the [International Republican Institute](/wiki/International_Republican_Institute "International Republican Institute") found that 94% of Kyiv was ethnic Ukrainian, and 5% ethnic Russian.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-iri1-94)^ Most of the city's non-Slav population comprises Tatars, [South Caucasians](/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus "Peoples of the Caucasus"), and other peoples from the [former Soviet Union](/wiki/Former_Soviet_Union "Former Soviet Union").{#cite_ref-iri1_94-0}  

### Language statistics {#Language_statistics}

Both Ukrainian and Russian are commonly spoken in the city; approximately 75% of Kyiv's population responded "Ukrainian" to the 2001 census question on their native language, roughly 25% responded "Russian".^[\[92\]](#cite_note-CensusKiev-95)^ According to a 2006 survey, Ukrainian is used at home by 23% of Kyivans, 52% use Russian, and 24% switch between both.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-ZerkaloKiev-96)^ In the 2003 sociological survey, when the question "What language do you use in everyday life?" was asked, 52% said "mostly Russian", 32% "both Russian and Ukrainian in equal measure", 14% "mostly Ukrainian", and 4.3% "exclusively Ukrainian".^[\[94\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}

According to the census of 1897, of Kyiv's approximately 240,000 people approximately 56% of the population spoke the Russian language, 23% spoke the Ukrainian language, 13% spoke Yiddish, 7% spoke Polish and 1% spoke the Belarusian language.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-98)^{#cite_ref-98}

A 2015 study by the International Republican Institute found that the languages spoken at home in Kyiv were Ukrainian (27%), Russian (32%), and an equal combination of Ukrainian and Russian (40%).^[\[91\]](#cite_note-iri1-94)^{#cite_ref-iri1_94-1}  

### Jews {#Jews}

Main article: [History of the Jews in Kyiv](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Kyiv "History of the Jews in Kyiv")

The Jews of Kyiv are first mentioned in a 10th-century letter. The Jewish population remained relatively small until the nineteenth century.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-jewishvirtuallibrary.org-99)^ A series of [pogroms](/wiki/Pogrom "Pogrom") was carried out in 1882, and another in 1905. On the eve of World War I, the city's Jewish population was over 81,000.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-100)^ In 1939 there were approximately 224,000 Jews in Kyiv,^[\[96\]](#cite_note-jewishvirtuallibrary.org-99)^ some of whom fled the city ahead of the [German invasion](/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa "Operation Barbarossa") of the Soviet Union that began in June 1941. On 29 and 30 September 1941, nearly 34,000 Kyivan Jews were massacred at Babi Yar by the Wehrmacht, [SS](/wiki/SS "SS"), [Ukrainian Auxiliary Police](/wiki/Ukrainian_Auxiliary_Police "Ukrainian Auxiliary Police"), and local collaborators.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-101)^^[\[99\]](#cite_note-102)^{#cite_ref-102}

Jews began returning to Kyiv at the end of the war, but experienced another pogrom in September 1945.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-103)^ In the 21st century, Kyiv's Jewish community numbers about 20,000. There are two major synagogues in the city: the [Great Choral Synagogue](/wiki/Great_Choral_Synagogue_(Kyiv) "Great Choral Synagogue (Kyiv)") and the [Brodsky Choral Synagogue](/wiki/Brodsky_Choral_Synagogue "Brodsky Choral Synagogue").^[\[101\]](#cite_note-104)^{#cite_ref-104}  

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

See also: [Category:Buildings and structures in Kyiv](/wiki/Category:Buildings_and_structures_in_Kyiv "Category:Buildings and structures in Kyiv")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Panorama_of_Podil.jpg/1318px-Panorama_of_Podil.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_of_Podil.jpg "A panoramic view of Podil, one of Kyiv's central neighborhoods")  
[](/wiki/File:Panorama_of_Podil.jpg "File:Panorama of Podil.jpg")  
A [panoramic](/wiki/Panorama "Panorama") view of [Podil](/wiki/Podil "Podil"), one of Kyiv's central neighborhoods

Modern Kyiv is a mix of the old (Kyiv preserved about 70 percent of more than 1,000 buildings built during 1907--1914)^[\[102\]](#cite_note-Forgotten_Soviet_Plans_For_Kyiv-105)^ and the new, seen in everything from the architecture to the stores and to the people themselves. When the capital of the [Ukrainian SSR](/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR "Ukrainian SSR") was moved from [Kharkiv](/wiki/Kharkiv "Kharkiv") to Kyiv many new buildings were commissioned to give the city "the gloss and polish of a capital".^[\[102\]](#cite_note-Forgotten_Soviet_Plans_For_Kyiv-105)^ In the discussions that centered on how to create a showcase city center, the current city center of Khreshchatyk and [Maidan Nezalezhnosti](/wiki/Maidan_Nezalezhnosti "Maidan Nezalezhnosti") (Independence Square) were not the obvious choices.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-Forgotten_Soviet_Plans_For_Kyiv-105)^ Some of the early, ultimately not materialised, ideas included a part of Pechersk, [Lypky](/wiki/Lypky "Lypky"), [European Square](/wiki/European_Square,_Kyiv "European Square, Kyiv"), and [Mykhailivska Square](/wiki/Mykhailivska_Square "Mykhailivska Square").^[\[102\]](#cite_note-Forgotten_Soviet_Plans_For_Kyiv-105)^{#cite_ref-Forgotten_Soviet_Plans_For_Kyiv_105-3}

The plans of building massive monuments (of [Vladimir Lenin](/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin "Vladimir Lenin") and Stalin) were also abandoned, due to lack of money (in the 1930s--1950s) and because of Kyiv's hilly landscape.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-Forgotten_Soviet_Plans_For_Kyiv-105)^ Experiencing rapid population growth between the 1970s and the mid-1990s, the city has continued its consistent growth after the turn of the millennium. As a result, Kyiv's central districts provide a dotted contrast of new, modern buildings among the pale yellows, blues, and greys of older apartments. [Urban sprawl](/wiki/Urban_sprawl "Urban sprawl") has gradually reduced, while population densities of suburbs has increased. The most expensive properties are in the Pechersk and Khreshchatyk areas. It is also prestigious to own a property in newly constructed buildings in the [Kharkivskyi neighborhood](/wiki/Kharkivskyi_Masyv "Kharkivskyi Masyv") or [Obolon](/wiki/Obolon_Raion "Obolon Raion") along the Dnieper.{#cite_ref-Forgotten_Soviet_Plans_For_Kyiv_105-4}

Ukrainian independence at the turn of the millennium has heralded other changes. Western-style residential complexes, modern [nightclubs](/wiki/Nightclub "Nightclub"), classy restaurants and prestigious hotels opened in the centre. And most importantly, with the easing of the visa rules in 2005,^[\[103\]](#cite_note-106)^ Ukraine is positioning itself as a prime tourist attraction, with Kyiv, among the other large cities, looking to profit from new opportunities. The centre of Kyiv has been cleaned up and buildings have been restored and redecorated, especially Khreshchatyk and Maidan Nezalezhnosti. Many historic areas of Kyiv, such as [Andriivskyi Descent](/wiki/Andriivskyi_Descent "Andriivskyi Descent"), have become popular street vendor locations, where one can find traditional [Ukrainian art](/wiki/Art_of_Ukraine "Art of Ukraine"), religious items, books, game sets (most commonly [chess](/wiki/Chess "Chess")) as well as jewellery for sale.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-107)^{#cite_ref-107}

At the [United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009](/wiki/2009_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference "2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference"), Kyiv was the only [Commonwealth of Independent States](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States "Commonwealth of Independent States") city to have been inscribed into the TOP30 European Green City Index (placed 30th).^[\[105\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

Kyiv's most famous historical architecture complexes are the [St. Sophia Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Sophia_Cathedral,_Kyiv "Saint Sophia Cathedral, Kyiv") and the [Kyiv Pechersk Lavra](/wiki/Kyiv_Pechersk_Lavra "Kyiv Pechersk Lavra") (Monastery of the Caves), which are recognized by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") as a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site"). Noteworthy historical architectural landmarks also include the [Mariinskyi Palace](/wiki/Mariinskyi_Palace "Mariinskyi Palace") (designed and constructed from 1745 to 1752, then reconstructed in 1870), several [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") churches such as [St. Michael's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery "St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery"), [St. Andrew's](/wiki/St_Andrew%27s_Church,_Kyiv "St Andrew's Church, Kyiv"), [St. Volodymyr's](/wiki/St_Volodymyr%27s_Cathedral "St Volodymyr's Cathedral"), [St. Cyril's](/wiki/St._Cyril%27s_Monastery,_Kyiv "St. Cyril's Monastery, Kyiv"), the reconstructed [Golden Gate](/wiki/Golden_Gate,_Kyiv "Golden Gate, Kyiv") and others.

One of Kyiv's widely recognized modern landmarks is the highly visible giant [Mother Ukraine](/wiki/Mother_Ukraine "Mother Ukraine") statue made of titanium standing at the [National Museum of the History of Ukraine in the Second World War](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_History_of_Ukraine_in_the_Second_World_War "National Museum of the History of Ukraine in the Second World War") on the Right bank of the Dnieper. Other notable sites is the cylindrical Salut hotel, across from Glory Square and the [eternal flame](/wiki/Eternal_flame "Eternal flame") at the World War Two memorial [Tomb of the Unknown Soldier](/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier_(Kyiv) "Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (Kyiv)"), and the [House with Chimaeras](/wiki/House_with_Chimaeras "House with Chimaeras").

Among Kyiv's best-known monuments are [Mikhail Mikeshin](/wiki/Mikhail_Mikeshin "Mikhail Mikeshin")'s statue of [Bohdan Khmelnytsky](/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky "Bohdan Khmelnytsky") astride his horse near [St. Sophia Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Sophia_Cathedral,_Kyiv "Saint Sophia Cathedral, Kyiv"), the venerated [Vladimir the Great](/wiki/Vladimir_the_Great "Vladimir the Great") (St. Vladimir), the [baptizer of Rus'](/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27 "Christianization of Kievan Rus'"), overlooking the river above Podil from [Saint Volodymyr Hill](/wiki/Saint_Volodymyr_Hill "Saint Volodymyr Hill"), the monument to Kyi, Shchek and Khoryv and Lybid, the legendary founders of the city at the Dnieper embankment. On Independence Square in the city centre, two monuments elevate two of the city protectors; the historic protector of Kyiv Michael Archangel atop a reconstruction of one of the old city's gates and a modern invention, the goddess-protector [Berehynia](/wiki/Berehynia "Berehynia") atop a tall column.

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

See also: [Category:Culture in Kyiv](/wiki/Category:Culture_in_Kyiv "Category:Culture in Kyiv")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/National_Opera_of_Ukraine_P1150634.jpg/180px-National_Opera_of_Ukraine_P1150634.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Opera_of_Ukraine_P1150634.jpg) The [Kyiv National Opera House](/wiki/Kyiv_Opera_House "Kyiv Opera House") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Kiev_Academic_Puppet_Theatre_%286%29.jpg/180px-Kiev_Academic_Puppet_Theatre_%286%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kiev_Academic_Puppet_Theatre_(6).jpg) The [Kyiv Academic Puppet Theatre](/wiki/Kyiv_Academic_Puppet_Theatre "Kyiv Academic Puppet Theatre") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Esc_2005_concert_on_maidan.jpg/180px-Esc_2005_concert_on_maidan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Esc_2005_concert_on_maidan.jpg) A public concert held on [Maidan Nezalezhnosti](/wiki/Maidan_Nezalezhnosti "Maidan Nezalezhnosti") during Kyiv's 2005 Eurovision Song Contest

Kyiv was the historic cultural centre of the [East Slavic](/wiki/East_Slavs "East Slavs") civilization and a major cradle for the [Christianization of Kievan Rus](/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus "Christianization of Kievan Rus"). Kyiv retained through centuries its cultural importance and even at times of relative decay, it remained the centre of primary importance of Eastern Orthodox Christianity. Its sacred sites of Kyiv Pechersk Lavra (the Monastery of the Caves) and the Saint Sophia Cathedral are attracting pilgrims for centuries and recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, remaining the primary religious centres as well as major tourist attractions. The above-mentioned sites are also part of the [Seven Wonders of Ukraine](/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_Ukraine "Seven Wonders of Ukraine") collection.

In September 2023, the UNESCO World Heritage Committee placed the Saint Sophia Cathedral and Kyiv Pechersk Lavra on the [List of World Heritage in Danger](/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_in_Danger "List of World Heritage in Danger"). According to the committee, although the Ukrainian government has taken action to protect the sites, "optimal conditions are no longer met to fully guarantee the protection of the Outstanding Universal Value of the property and that it is threatened by potential danger due to the war". The list is protected by the [1972 UNESCO Convention](/wiki/World_Heritage_Convention "World Heritage Convention"), ratified by both Russia and Ukraine. Inclusion on the list is intended to mobilize urgent international support.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-109)^^[\[107\]](#cite_note-110)^^[\[108\]](#cite_note-111)^{#cite_ref-111}

Kyiv's theatres include the [Kyiv Opera House](/wiki/Kyiv_Opera_House "Kyiv Opera House"), [Ivan Franko National Academic Drama Theater](/wiki/Ivan_Franko_National_Academic_Drama_Theater "Ivan Franko National Academic Drama Theater"), [Lesya Ukrainka National Academic Theater](/wiki/Lesya_Ukrainka_National_Academic_Theater "Lesya Ukrainka National Academic Theater"), the [Kyiv Puppet Theater](/wiki/Kyiv_Academic_Puppet_Theatre "Kyiv Academic Puppet Theatre"), [October Palace](/wiki/October_Palace "October Palace"), [National Philharmonic of Ukraine](/wiki/National_Philharmonic_of_Ukraine "National Philharmonic of Ukraine") and others. In 1946 Kyiv had four theatres, one opera house and one concert hall,^[\[109\]](#cite_note-life-112)^ but most tickets then were allocated to "privileged groups".^[\[109\]](#cite_note-life-112)^{#cite_ref-life_112-1}

Other significant cultural centres include the [Dovzhenko Film Studios](/wiki/Dovzhenko_Film_Studios "Dovzhenko Film Studios"), and the Kyiv Circus. The most important of the [city's many museums](/wiki/Category:Museums_in_Kyiv "Category:Museums in Kyiv") are the [National Museum of the History of Ukraine](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_History_of_Ukraine "National Museum of the History of Ukraine"), the [National Museum of the History of Ukraine in the Second World War](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_History_of_Ukraine_in_the_Second_World_War "National Museum of the History of Ukraine in the Second World War"), the [National Art Museum](/wiki/National_Art_Museum_of_Ukraine "National Art Museum of Ukraine"), the [Museum of Western and Oriental Art](/wiki/Khanenko_Museum "Khanenko Museum"), the [Pinchuk Art Centre](/wiki/PinchukArtCentre "PinchukArtCentre"), the Kyiv Picture Gallery National Museum, and the [Ivan Honchar Museum](/wiki/Ivan_Honchar_Museum "Ivan Honchar Museum").

In 2005, Kyiv hosted the [50th annual](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2005 "Eurovision Song Contest 2005") [Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest "Eurovision Song Contest") and in 2017 the [62nd annual](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2017 "Eurovision Song Contest 2017") Eurovision Song Contest.

Numerous songs and paintings were dedicated to the city. Some songs became part of Russian, Ukrainian and Jewish folklore. The most popular songs are "[How not to love you, Kyiv of mine?](/wiki/Yak_tebe_ne_liubyty,_Kyieve_mii! "Yak tebe ne liubyty, Kyieve mii!")" and "Kyiv Waltz". Renowned Ukrainian composer [Oleksandr Bilash](/wiki/Oleksandr_Bilash "Oleksandr Bilash") wrote an operetta called "Legend of Kyiv".  

### Attractions {#Attractions}

See also: [List of public art in Kyiv](/wiki/List_of_public_art_in_Kyiv "List of public art in Kyiv")

It is said that one can walk from one end of Kyiv to the other in the summertime without leaving the shade of its many trees. Most characteristic are the [horse-chestnuts](/wiki/Aesculus_hippocastanum "Aesculus hippocastanum") (каштани, *kashtany*).

Kyiv is known as a green city with [two botanical gardens](/wiki/M.M._Gryshko_National_Botanical_Garden "M.M. Gryshko National Botanical Garden") and numerous large and small parks. The National Museum of the History of Ukraine in the Second World War is here, which offers both indoor and outdoor displays of military history and equipment surrounded by verdant hills overlooking the Dnieper river.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9.JPG/140px-%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9.JPG)](/wiki/File:%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9.JPG)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C.JPG/158px-%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C.JPG)](/wiki/File:%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%A5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C.JPG)  
The [monument](/wiki/Monument_to_Prince_Volodymyr "Monument to Prince Volodymyr") to [St. Volodymyr, the Baptiser of Rus'](/wiki/Saint_Vladimir_Monument "Saint Vladimir Monument"), overlooking from [Saint Vladimir Hill](/wiki/Saint_Vladimir_Hill "Saint Vladimir Hill") the scenic panorama of the left bank of Dnieper, is one of the symbols of Kyiv, often depicted in paintings and photographic works of the city.

Among the numerous islands, Venetsiiskyi (or [Hydropark](/wiki/Hydropark_in_Kyiv "Hydropark in Kyiv")) is the most developed. It is accessible by metro or by car, and includes an amusement park, swimming beaches, boat rentals, and night clubs. Other major islands include [Trukhaniv](/wiki/Trukhaniv_Island "Trukhaniv Island"), Muromets, and Dolobetskyi. The Victory Park (*Park Peremohy* ) near Darnytsia subway station is a popular destination for strollers, joggers, and cyclists. Boating, fishing, and water sports are popular pastimes in Kyiv. The area lakes and rivers freeze over in the winter and ice fishermen are a frequent sight, as are children with their ice skates. However, the peak of summer draws out a greater mass of people to the shores for swimming or sunbathing, with daytime high temperatures sometimes reaching 30 to 34 °C (86 to 93 °F).^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Vydubychi_Monastery_2008%28Kiev%29.JPG/220px-Vydubychi_Monastery_2008%28Kiev%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Vydubychi_Monastery_2008(Kiev).JPG) Lilacs in the National Botanical Garden, with the [Vydubychi Monastery](/wiki/Vydubychi_Monastery "Vydubychi Monastery"), Darnytskyi Rail Bridge and left-bank Kyiv visible in the background

The centre of Kyiv ([Maidan Nezalezhnosti](/wiki/Maidan_Nezalezhnosti "Maidan Nezalezhnosti") and [Khreshchatyk Street](/wiki/Khreshchatyk "Khreshchatyk")) becomes a large outdoor party place at night during summer months, with thousands of people having a good time in nearby restaurants, clubs and outdoor cafes. The central streets are closed for auto traffic on weekends and holidays. [Andriivskyi Descent](/wiki/Andriivskyi_Descent "Andriivskyi Descent") is one of the best known historic streets and a major tourist attraction in Kyiv. The hill is the site of the Castle of Richard the Lionheart; the baroque-style [St Andrew's Church](/wiki/St_Andrew%27s_Church,_Kyiv "St Andrew's Church, Kyiv"); the [home](/wiki/Mikhail_Bulgakov_Museum "Mikhail Bulgakov Museum") of the Kyiv-born writer [Mikhail Bulgakov](/wiki/Mikhail_Bulgakov "Mikhail Bulgakov"); the monument to [Yaroslav the Wise](/wiki/Yaroslav_the_Wise "Yaroslav the Wise"), the Grand Prince of Kyiv and [Novgorod](/wiki/Veliky_Novgorod "Veliky Novgorod"); and numerous other monuments.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-Sights_of_Kiev-113)^^[\[111\]](#cite_note-114)^{#cite_ref-114}

A wide variety of farm produce is available in many of Kyiv's farmer markets with the [Bessarabskyi Market](/wiki/Bessarabskyi_Market "Bessarabskyi Market") in the very centre of the city being most famous. Each residential region has its own market, or *rynok* . Here one will find table after table of individuals hawking everything imaginable: vegetables, fresh and smoked meats, fish, cheese, honey, dairy products such as milk and home-made *[smetana](/wiki/Smetana_(dairy_product) "Smetana (dairy product)")* (sour cream), [caviar](/wiki/Caviar "Caviar"), cut flowers, housewares, tools and hardware, and clothing. Each of the markets has its own unique mix of products with some markets devoted solely to specific wares such as automobiles, car parts, pets, clothing, flowers, and other things.

At the city's southern outskirts, near the historic [Pyrohiv](/wiki/Pyrohiv "Pyrohiv") village, there is an [outdoor museum](/wiki/Open-air_museum "Open-air museum") officially called the [Museum of Folk Architecture and Life of Ukraine](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Folk_Architecture_and_Folkways_of_Ukraine "National Museum of Folk Architecture and Folkways of Ukraine"). It has an area of 1.5 square kilometres (1 sq mi). This territory houses several "mini-villages" that represent by region the traditional rural architecture of Ukraine.

Kyiv also has numerous recreational attractions like bowling alleys, go-cart tracks, paintball venues, billiard halls and even shooting ranges. The 100-year-old [Kyiv Zoo](/wiki/Kyiv_Zoo "Kyiv Zoo") is on 40 hectares and according to CBC "the zoo has 2,600 animals from 328 species".^[\[112\]](#cite_note-CBCAP-115)^{#cite_ref-CBCAP_115-0}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Panorama_golden_domed_St_Michael%27s_Kiev.jpg/1367px-Panorama_golden_domed_St_Michael%27s_Kiev.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_golden_domed_St_Michael%27s_Kiev.jpg "A panoramic view of Mykhailiv Square (central Kyiv). From left to right: the Diplomatic Academy, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (behind the monument to Princess Olga) and St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery.")  
[](/wiki/File:Panorama_golden_domed_St_Michael%27s_Kiev.jpg "File:Panorama golden domed St Michael's Kiev.jpg")
