From left to right: the Diplomatic Academy, [Ministry of Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Ukraine "Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine") (behind the monument to Princess Olga) and [St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery](/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery "St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery").  

### Museums and galleries {#Museums_and_galleries}

See also: [Museums in Kyiv](/wiki/Museums_in_Kyiv "Museums in Kyiv")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%86%D1%96%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%96%D1%97_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_2015_%D1%80..jpg/220px-%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%86%D1%96%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%96%D1%97_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8%2C_2015_%D1%80..jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%86%D1%96%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D1%96%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%96%D1%97_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B8,_2015_%D1%80..jpg) The [National Historical Museum of Ukraine](/wiki/National_Historical_Museum_of_Ukraine "National Historical Museum of Ukraine")

Kyiv is home to some 40 different museums.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-CULKSO-116)^ In 2009 they recorded a total of 4.3 million visits.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-CULKSO-116)^{#cite_ref-CULKSO_116-1}

The National Museum of the History of Ukraine in the Second World War is a memorial complex commemorating the Eastern Front of World War II in the hills on the [right-bank](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Kyiv#Historical_neighborhoods "Subdivisions of Kyiv") of the Dnieper in [Pechersk](/wiki/Pechersk,_Kyiv "Pechersk, Kyiv"). [Kyiv Fortress](/wiki/Kyiv_Fortress "Kyiv Fortress") is the 19th-century [fortification](/wiki/Fortification "Fortification") buildings situated in [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine") capital Kyiv, that once belonged to [western Russian fortresses](/wiki/Western_Russian_fortresses "Western Russian fortresses"). These structures (once a united complex) were built in the Pechersk and neighbourhoods by the Russian army. Some of the buildings are restored and turned into a museum, while others are in use in various military and commercial installations.

The National Art Museum of Ukraine is a museum dedicated to Ukrainian art. The [Golden Gate](/wiki/Golden_Gate,_Kyiv "Golden Gate, Kyiv") is a historic gateway in the ancient city's walls. The name *Zoloti Vorota* (Golden Gate) is also used for a nearby theatre and [a station](/wiki/Zoloti_Vorota_(Kyiv_Metro) "Zoloti Vorota (Kyiv Metro)") of the [Kyiv Metro](/wiki/Kyiv_Metro "Kyiv Metro"). The small [Ukrainian National Chernobyl Museum](/wiki/Ukrainian_National_Chernobyl_Museum "Ukrainian National Chernobyl Museum") acts as both a memorial and historical center devoted to the events surrounding the 1986 Chernobyl disaster and its effect on the Ukrainian people, the environment, and subsequent attitudes toward the safety of [nuclear power](/wiki/Nuclear_power "Nuclear power") as a whole.  

### Sports {#Sports}

See also: [Category:Sport in Kyiv](/wiki/Category:Sport_in_Kyiv "Category:Sport in Kyiv")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%96%D0%B3_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8_%282011%29._%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82..jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%96%D0%B3_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8_%282011%29._%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82..jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%96%D0%B3_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8_(2011)._%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82..jpg) The annual 5.5-kilometre (3.4-mile) "Run under the Chestnuts" is a popular public sporting event in Kyiv, with hundreds taking part every year.

Kyiv has many professional and amateur football clubs, including [Dynamo Kyiv](/wiki/FC_Dynamo_Kyiv "FC Dynamo Kyiv"), [Arsenal Kyiv](/wiki/FC_Arsenal_Kyiv "FC Arsenal Kyiv") and [FC Obolon Kyiv](/wiki/FC_Obolon_Kyiv "FC Obolon Kyiv") but only Dynamo Kyiv play in the [Ukrainian Premier League](/wiki/Ukrainian_Premier_League "Ukrainian Premier League"). Of these three, Dynamo Kyiv has had the most success over the course of its history. For example, up until the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, the club won 13 [USSR Championships](/wiki/Soviet_Top_League "Soviet Top League"), 9 [USSR Cups](/wiki/USSR_Cup "USSR Cup"), and 3 [USSR Super Cups](/wiki/USSR_Super_Cup "USSR Super Cup"), thus making Dynamo the most successful club in the history of the Soviet Top League.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-trophy-117)^{#cite_ref-trophy_117-0}

Other prominent non-football sport clubs in the city include: the [Sokil Kyiv](/wiki/Sokil_Kyiv "Sokil Kyiv") ice hockey club and [BC Budivelnyk](/wiki/BC_Budivelnyk "BC Budivelnyk") basketball club. Both of these teams play in the highest Ukrainian leagues for their respective sports. Budivelnyk was founded in 1945, Sokil was founded in 1963, during the existence of the Soviet Union. Both these teams play their home games at the [Kyiv Palace of Sports](/wiki/Palace_of_Sports_(Kyiv) "Palace of Sports (Kyiv)").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Kyiv_NSC_Olimpiyskyi_5.jpg/220px-Kyiv_NSC_Olimpiyskyi_5.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kyiv_NSC_Olimpiyskyi_5.jpg) [Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex](/wiki/Olimpiyskiy_National_Sports_Complex "Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex")

During the [1980 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics "1980 Summer Olympics") held in the Soviet Union, Kyiv held the preliminary matches and the quarter-finals of the football tournament at its [Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Olimpiyskiy_National_Sports_Complex "Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex"), which was reconstructed specially for the event. From 1 December 2008, the stadium underwent a full-scale reconstruction in order to satisfy standards put in place by [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") for hosting the [Euro 2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012") football tournament; the opening ceremony took place in the presence of president [Viktor Yanukovych](/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych "Viktor Yanukovych") on 8 October 2011,^[\[115\]](#cite_note-YanuBOO-118)^ with the first major event being a [Shakira](/wiki/Shakira "Shakira") concert which was specially planned to coincide with the stadium's re-opening during Euro 2012. Other notable sport stadiums/sport complexes in Kyiv include the [Valeriy Lobanovskyi Dynamo Stadium](/wiki/Valeriy_Lobanovskyi_Dynamo_Stadium "Valeriy Lobanovskyi Dynamo Stadium"), the [Palace of Sports](/wiki/Palace_of_Sports,_Kyiv "Palace of Sports, Kyiv"), among many others.{#cite_ref-YanuBOO_118-0}

Most Ukrainian national teams play their home international matches in Kyiv. The [Ukraine national football team](/wiki/Ukraine_national_football_team "Ukraine national football team"), for example, will play matches at the re-constructed Olympic Stadium from 2011.  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

See also: [Category:Tourist attractions in Kyiv](/wiki/Category:Tourist_attractions_in_Kyiv "Category:Tourist attractions in Kyiv")

Since introducing a visa-free regime for EU-member states and Switzerland in 2005, Ukraine has seen a steady increase in the number of foreign tourists visiting the country.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-119)^ Before the [2008--2009 Ukrainian financial crisis](/wiki/2008%E2%80%932009_Ukrainian_financial_crisis "2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis"), the average annual growth in the number of foreign visits in Kyiv was 23% over a three-year period.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-touristsstat-120)^ In 2009, a total of 1.6 million tourists stayed in Kyiv hotels, of whom almost 259,000 ( 16%) were foreigners.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-touristsstat-120)^{#cite_ref-touristsstat_120-1}

After UEFA Euro 2012, the city became the most popular destination for European tourists. A record number of 1.8 million foreign tourists was registered then along with about 2.5 million domestic tourists. More than 850,000 foreign tourists visited Kyiv in the first half of 2018, as compared to 660,000 tourists over the same period in 2013. As of 2018, the hotel occupancy rate from May to September averages 45--50%. Hostels and three-star hotels are approximately 90% full, four-star hotels 65--70%. Six five-star hotels average 50--55% occupancy. Ordinary tourists generally come from May to October, and business tourists from September to May.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-121)^{#cite_ref-121}  

### City anthem {#City_anthem}

In 2014, the Kyiv city's council established the city's anthem.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-anthem-122)^ It became a 1962 song, "[Yak tebe ne liubyty, Kyieve mii!](/wiki/Yak_tebe_ne_liubyty,_Kyieve_mii! "Yak tebe ne liubyty, Kyieve mii!")"^[\[119\]](#cite_note-anthem-122)^ (Як тебе не любити, Києве мій!, roughly "How can I not love you, Kyiv of mine!").{#cite_ref-anthem_122-1}  

### City symbols {#City_symbols}

The [horse chestnut tree](/wiki/Aesculus_hippocastanum "Aesculus hippocastanum") is one of the symbols of Kyiv.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-7253616chestnutKyivD-123)^ It was heavily present on the [city's coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Kyiv "Coat of arms of Kyiv") used from 1969 to 1995.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-7253616chestnutKyivD-123)^{#cite_ref-7253616chestnutKyivD_123-1}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

See also: [Category:Economy of Kyiv](/wiki/Category:Economy_of_Kyiv "Category:Economy of Kyiv") and [Economy of Ukraine](/wiki/Economy_of_Ukraine "Economy of Ukraine")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%89%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA_38_%D0%B4%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%8C_2_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_2012_01.JPG/220px-%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%89%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA_38_%D0%B4%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%8C_2_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_2012_01.JPG)](/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%89%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA_38_%D0%B4%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%8C_2_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_2012_01.JPG) The [TsUM](/wiki/TSUM_Kyiv "TSUM Kyiv") [department store](/wiki/Department_store "Department store")

As with most [capital cities](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city"), Kyiv is a major administrative, cultural, and scientific centre of the country. It is the largest city in Ukraine in terms of both population and area and enjoys the highest levels of business activity. On 1 January 2010, there were around 238,000 [business entities](/wiki/List_of_company_registers#Ukraine "List of company registers") registered in Kyiv.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-124)^{#cite_ref-124}

Official figures show that between 2004 and 2008 Kyiv's economy outstripped the rest of the country's, growing by an annual average of 11.5%.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-GDPKSO-125)^^[\[123\]](#cite_note-GDPSSC-126)^ Following the [Great Recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"), Kyiv's economy suffered a severe setback in 2009 with [gross regional product](/wiki/Gross_regional_product "Gross regional product") contracting by 13.5% in real terms.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-GDPKSO-125)^ Although a record high, the decline in activity was 1.6 [percentage points](/wiki/Percentage_points "Percentage points") smaller than that for the country as a whole.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-GDPSSC-126)^ The economy in Kyiv, as in the rest of Ukraine, recovered somewhat in 2010 and 2011. Kyiv is a middle-income city, with prices comparable to many mid-size American cities (i.e., considerably lower than Western Europe).{#cite_ref-GDPSSC_126-1}

Because the city has a large and diverse economic base and is not dependent on any single industry or company, its unemployment rate has historically been relatively low -- only 3.75% over 2005--2008.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-JOBKSO-127)^ Indeed, even as the rate of joblessness jumped to 7.1% in 2009, it remained far below the national average of 9.6%.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-JOBKSO-127)^^[\[125\]](#cite_note-JOBSSC-128)^{#cite_ref-JOBSSC_128-0}

As of January 2022, the average monthly salary in Kyiv reached 21,347 [UAH](/wiki/Ukrainian_hryvnia "Ukrainian hryvnia") (€540) gross and 17,184 UAH (€430) net.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-129)^^[\[127\]](#cite_note-130)^^[\[128\]](#cite_note-131)^{#cite_ref-131}

Kyiv is the undisputed center of business and commerce of Ukraine and home to the country's largest companies, such as [Naftogaz Ukrainy](/wiki/Naftogaz "Naftogaz"), [Energorynok](/w/index.php?title=Energorynok&action=edit&redlink=1 "Energorynok (page does not exist)") and [Kyivstar](/wiki/Kyivstar "Kyivstar"). In 2010, the city accounted for 18% of national [retail sales](/wiki/Retail_sales "Retail sales") and 24% of all construction activity.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-RSKSO-132)^^[\[130\]](#cite_note-RSSSC-133)^^[\[131\]](#cite_note-CWKSO-134)^^[\[132\]](#cite_note-CWSSC-135)^ Real estate is one of the major forces in Kyiv's economy. Average prices of [apartments](/wiki/Apartments "Apartments") are the highest in the country and among the highest in eastern Europe.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-136)^ Kyiv also ranks high in terms of [commercial real estate](/wiki/Commercial_real_estate "Commercial real estate") and has Ukraine's tallest [office buildings](/wiki/Office_building "Office building") (such as [Gulliver](/wiki/Gulliver_(building) "Gulliver (building)") and [Parus](/wiki/Parus_Business_Centre "Parus Business Centre")) and some of Ukraine's biggest shopping malls (such as [Dream Town](/w/index.php?title=Dream_Town&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dream Town (page does not exist)") and [Ocean Plaza](/wiki/Ocean_Plaza "Ocean Plaza")).{#cite_ref-136}

In May 2011, Kyiv authorities presented a 15-year development strategy which calls for attracting as much as EUR82 billion of [foreign investment](/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment "Foreign direct investment") by 2025 to modernize the city's transport and utilities infrastructure and make it more attractive for tourists.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}

### Industry {#Industry}

Primary [industries](/wiki/Industry_(economics) "Industry (economics)") in Kyiv include [utilities](/wiki/Public_utility "Public utility") -- i.e., electricity, gas and water supply (26% of total [industrial output](/wiki/Output_(economics) "Output (economics)")), manufacture of food, beverages and tobacco products (22%), [chemical](/wiki/Chemical_industry "Chemical industry") (17%), [mechanical engineering](/wiki/Mechanical_engineering "Mechanical engineering") (13%) and manufacture of paper and paper products, including publishing, printing and reproduction of recorded media (11%).^[\[139\]](#cite_note-IPKSO-142)^ The [Institute of Oil Transportation](/w/index.php?title=Institute_of_Oil_Transportation&action=edit&redlink=1 "Institute of Oil Transportation (page does not exist)") is headquartered here.{#cite_ref-IPKSO_142-0}  

### Manufacture {#Manufacture}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Antonov_An-124-100M_Ruslan%2C_Antonov_Design_Bureau_AN2177099.jpg/220px-Antonov_An-124-100M_Ruslan%2C_Antonov_Design_Bureau_AN2177099.jpg)](/wiki/File:Antonov_An-124-100M_Ruslan,_Antonov_Design_Bureau_AN2177099.jpg) The [An-124](/wiki/Antonov_An-124_Ruslan "Antonov An-124 Ruslan"), the largest aircraft ever mass-produced, designed by [Antonov](/wiki/Antonov "Antonov") in Kyiv

* [Kuznia na Rybalskomu](/wiki/Kuznia_na_Rybalskomu "Kuznia na Rybalskomu"), naval production
* [Antonov Serial Production Plant](/wiki/Antonov_Serial_Production_Plant "Antonov Serial Production Plant") (former Aviant), airplanes manufacturing
* [Aeros](/wiki/Aeros "Aeros"), small aircraft production
* [Kyiv Roshen Factory](/wiki/Kyiv_Roshen_Factory "Kyiv Roshen Factory"), confectionery
* [Kyiv Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_Factory "Arsenal Factory") (former arms manufacturer), specializes in production of optic-precision instruments
* [Obolon](/wiki/Obolon_(company) "Obolon (company)"), brewery
* [Kyiv Aircraft Repair Plant 410](/wiki/Kyiv_Aircraft_Repair_Plant_410 "Kyiv Aircraft Repair Plant 410"), repair factory at [Zhuliany Airport](/wiki/Kyiv_International_Airport_(Zhuliany) "Kyiv International Airport (Zhuliany)")

Education and science {#Education_and_science}
----------------------------------------------

See also: [Category:Education in Kyiv](/wiki/Category:Education_in_Kyiv "Category:Education in Kyiv")  

### Scientific research {#Scientific_research}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_54_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_2010_01.JPG/220px-%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_54_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_2010_01.JPG)](/wiki/File:%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_54_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_2010_01.JPG) The Ukrainian Academy of Sciences is based in Kyiv.

Scientific research is conducted in many institutes of higher education and, additionally, in many [research institutes](/wiki/Research_institute "Research institute") affiliated with the [Ukrainian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Sciences_of_Ukraine "National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine"). Kyiv is home to [Ukraine's ministry of education and science](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_and_Science_of_Ukraine "Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine"), and is also noted for its contributions to medical and computer science research.

In 2016, UNIT Factory (Ukrainian National IT Factory) opened. It offers a completely new format of IT education. The education is completely free for all trainees subject to compliance with the terms of the program. Within this project are the Technology Companies' Development Center (TCDC), BIONIC University open inter-corporate IT-university, as well as two hi-tech laboratories---VR Lab (Crytek) and Smart City lab.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}  

### University education {#University_education}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg/220px-Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg)](/wiki/File:Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg) National Taras Shevchenko University

Kyiv hosts many universities, the major ones being [Kyiv National Taras Shevchenko University](/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko_National_University_of_Kyiv "Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv"),^[\[141\]](#cite_note-144)^ the [National Technical University "Kyiv Polytechnic Institute"](/wiki/Kyiv_Polytechnic_Institute "Kyiv Polytechnic Institute"),^[\[142\]](#cite_note-145)^ [Kyiv-Mohyla Academy](/wiki/National_University_of_Kyiv-Mohyla_Academy "National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy")^[\[143\]](#cite_note-146)^ and the [Kyiv National University of Trade and Economics](/wiki/Kyiv_National_University_of_Trade_and_Economics "Kyiv National University of Trade and Economics"). Of these, the Mohyla Academy is the oldest, founded as a theological school in 1632, but Shevchenko University, founded in 1834, is the oldest in continuous operation. The total number of institutions of higher education in Kyiv approaches 200,^[\[144\]](#cite_note-147)^ allowing young people to pursue almost any line of study. While education traditionally remains largely in the hands of the state there are several accredited private institutions in the city.{#cite_ref-147}  

### Secondary education {#Secondary_education}

There are about 530 general secondary schools and about 680 nursery schools and [kindergartens](/wiki/Kindergarten "Kindergarten") in Kyiv.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-148)^ Additionally, there are evening schools for adults, specialist technical schools, and the [Evangel Theological Seminary](/wiki/Evangel_Theological_Seminary "Evangel Theological Seminary").{#cite_ref-148}  

### Public libraries {#Public_libraries}

There are many libraries in the city, with the [Vernadsky National Library](/wiki/Vernadsky_National_Library_of_Ukraine "Vernadsky National Library of Ukraine"), which is Ukraine's main [academic library](/wiki/Academic_library "Academic library") and scientific [information centre](/wiki/Information_centre "Information centre"), as well as one of the world's largest [national libraries](/wiki/National_library "National library"), being the largest and most important one.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-149)^ The National Library is affiliated with the Academy of Sciences in so far as it is a [deposit library](/wiki/Deposit_library "Deposit library") and thus serves as the academy's archives' store. The national library is the world's foremost repository of [Jewish folk music](/wiki/Jewish_music "Jewish music") recorded on [Edison wax cylinders](/wiki/Phonograph_cylinder "Phonograph cylinder"). Their Collection of Jewish Musical Folklore (1912--1947) was inscribed on UNESCO's [Memory of the World Register](/wiki/Memory_of_the_World_Register "Memory of the World Register") in 2005.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-mow-150)^{#cite_ref-mow_150-0}  

Infrastructure {#Infrastructure}
--------------------------------

### Transportation {#Transportation}

Main article: [Transport in Kyiv](/wiki/Transport_in_Kyiv "Transport in Kyiv")  

#### Local public transport {#Local_public_transport}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/%D0%95%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%9B%D0%90%D0%97-301_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BE_2.jpg/220px-%D0%95%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%9B%D0%90%D0%97-301_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BE_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%95%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%9B%D0%90%D0%97-301_%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BE_2.jpg) Trolleybus ElektroLAZ-301 at Sofia Square, passing by the [statue of Bohdan Khmelnytsky](/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky_Monument,_Kyiv "Bohdan Khmelnytsky Monument, Kyiv")

Local public transportation in Kyiv includes the Metro, buses and [minibuses](/wiki/Marshrutka "Marshrutka"), [trolleybuses](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus"), [trams](/wiki/Tram "Tram"), [taxi](/wiki/Taxicab "Taxicab") and [funicular](/wiki/Kyiv_Funicular "Kyiv Funicular"). There is also an [intra-city ring railway service](/wiki/Kyiv_Urban_Electric_Train "Kyiv Urban Electric Train").

The publicly owned and operated Kyiv Metro is the fastest, the most convenient and affordable network that covers most, but not all, of the city. The Metro is expanding towards the city limits to meet growing demand, having three lines with a total length of 66.1 kilometres (41.1 miles) and 51 stations (some of which are renowned architectural landmarks). The Metro carries around 1.422 million passengers daily^[\[148\]](#cite_note-update-151)^ accounting for 38% of the Kyiv's public transport load. In 2011, the total number of trips exceeded 519 million.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-update_151-0}

The historic tram system was the first electric tramway in the former Russian Empire and the third one in Europe after the [Berlin Straßembahn](/wiki/Trams_in_Berlin "Trams in Berlin") and the [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") tramway. The tram system consists of 139.9 km (86.9 mi) of track,^[\[149\]](#cite_note-152)^ including 14 km (8.7 mi) two [Rapid Tram](/wiki/Kyiv_Light_Rail "Kyiv Light Rail") lines, served by 21 routes with the use of 523 tram cars. Once a well maintained and widely used method of transport, the system is now gradually being phased out in favor of buses and trolleybuses.{#cite_ref-152}

The Kyiv Funicular was constructed during 1902--1905. It connects the historic [Uppertown](/wiki/Old_Kyiv "Old Kyiv"), and the lower commercial neighborhood of [Podil](/wiki/Podil "Podil") through the steep Saint Volodymyr Hill overseeing the Dnieper River. The line consists of two stations.

All public road transport (except for some minibuses) is operated by the united [Kyivpastrans](/wiki/Kyivpastrans "Kyivpastrans") municipal company. It is heavily subsidized by the city.

The Kyiv public transport system, except for taxi, uses a simple [flat rate](/wiki/Flat_rate "Flat rate") tariff system regardless of distance traveled: tickets or tokens must be purchased each time a vehicle is boarded. [Digital ticket](/wiki/Digital_ticket "Digital ticket") system is already established in Kyiv Metro, with plans for other transport modes. The cost of one ride is far lower than in Western Europe.

The taxi market in Kyiv is expansive but not regulated. In particular, the taxi fare per kilometer is not regulated. There is a fierce competition between private taxi companies.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/%D0%97%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D1%96_%D0%92%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%97%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D1%96_%D0%92%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B0.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%97%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D1%96_%D0%92%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B0.jpg) [Zoloti Vorota Metro Station Central Hall](/wiki/Zoloti_Vorota_(Kyiv_Metro) "Zoloti Vorota (Kyiv Metro)")  

#### Roads and bridges {#Roads_and_bridges}

Kyiv represents the focal point of Ukraine's "national roads" system, thus linked by road to all cities of the country. [European routes](/wiki/International_E-road_network "International E-road network") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Tabliczka_E40.svg/35px-Tabliczka_E40.svg.png)](/wiki/European_route_E40 "European route E40"), [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Tabliczka_E95.svg/35px-Tabliczka_E95.svg.png)](/wiki/European_route_E95 "European route E95") and [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Tabliczka_E373.svg/35px-Tabliczka_E373.svg.png)](/wiki/European_route_E373 "European route E373") intersect in Kyiv.

There are eight Dnieper bridges and dozens of [grade-separated](/wiki/Grade_separation "Grade separation") intersections in the city. Several new intersections are under construction. There are plans to build a full-size, fully grade-separated [ring road](/wiki/Ring_road "Ring road") around Kyiv.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-153)^^[\[151\]](#cite_note-154)^^[\[152\]](#cite_note-155)^{#cite_ref-155}

In 2009, Kyiv's roads were in poor technical condition and maintained inadequately.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}

[Traffic jams](/wiki/Traffic_congestion "Traffic congestion") and lack of parking space are growing problems for all road transport services in Kyiv.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Boryspil_International_Airport_Kyiv.jpg/220px-Boryspil_International_Airport_Kyiv.jpg)](/wiki/File:Boryspil_International_Airport_Kyiv.jpg) [Boryspil International Airport](/wiki/Boryspil_International_Airport "Boryspil International Airport")  

#### Air transport {#Air_transport}

Kyiv is served by two international passenger airports: the [Boryspil Airport](/wiki/Boryspil_International_Airport "Boryspil International Airport") 30 kilometres (19 miles) away, and the smaller, municipally owned [Zhuliany Airport](/wiki/Kyiv_International_Airport_(Zhuliany) "Kyiv International Airport (Zhuliany)") on the southern outskirts of the city. There are also the [Hostomel cargo airport](/wiki/Hostomel_Airport "Hostomel Airport") and additional three operating [airfields](/wiki/Airfield "Airfield") facilitating the [Antonov aircraft manufacturing company](/wiki/Antonov "Antonov") and [general aviation](/wiki/General_aviation "General aviation").  

#### Railways {#Railways}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2-%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_DSC_5417.jpg/220px-%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2-%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_DSC_5417.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2-%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_DSC_5417.jpg) [Kyiv-Pasazhyrskyi Railway Station](/wiki/Kyiv-Pasazhyrskyi_railway_station "Kyiv-Pasazhyrskyi railway station")

Railways are Kyiv's main mode of intracity- and suburban transportation. The city has a developed railroad infrastructure including a long-distance passenger station, 6 cargo stations, depots, and repairing facilities. However, this system still fails to meet the demand for passenger service. Particularly, the [Kyiv-Pasazhyrskyi railway station](/wiki/Kyiv-Pasazhyrskyi_railway_station "Kyiv-Pasazhyrskyi railway station") is the city's only long-distance passenger terminal (*vokzal*).

Construction is underway for turning the large [Darnytsia railway station](/wiki/Darnytsia_railway_station "Darnytsia railway station") on the left-bank part of Kyiv into a long-distance passenger hub, which may ease traffic at the central station.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-157)^ [Bridges over the Dnieper River](/wiki/Bridges_in_Kyiv "Bridges in Kyiv") are another problem restricting the development of city's railway system. Presently, only one rail bridge out of two is available for intense train traffic. A new combined rail-auto bridge is under construction, as a part of Darnytsia project.{#cite_ref-157}

In 2011, the Kyiv city administration established the new Urban Train for Kyiv. This service runs at standard 4- to 10-minute intervals throughout the day and follows a circular route around the city centre, which allows it to serve many of Kyiv's inner suburbs. Interchanges between the Kyiv Metro and Fast Tram exist at many of the urban train's station stops.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

Suburban 'Kyiv City Express' trains (colloquially known as *[elektrychka](/wiki/Elektrichka "Elektrichka")* ) are serviced by the publicly owned [Ukrainian Railways](/wiki/Ukrainian_Railways "Ukrainian Railways"). The suburban train service is fast, and unbeatably safe in terms of traffic accidents. But the trains are not reliable, as they may fall significantly behind schedule, may not be safe in terms of crime, and the *elektrychka* cars are poorly maintained and overcrowded in [rush hours](/wiki/Rush_hour "Rush hour").

There are nine *elektrychka* directions from Kyiv:^[\[156\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}

* [Bila Tserkva](/wiki/Bila_Tserkva "Bila Tserkva") -- [Uzyn](/wiki/Uzyn "Uzyn")
* [Fastiv](/wiki/Fastiv "Fastiv")
* [Klavdiievo](/wiki/Klavdiievo-Tarasove "Klavdiievo-Tarasove")
* [Myronivka](/wiki/Myronivka "Myronivka") -- [Bohuslav](/wiki/Bohuslav "Bohuslav")
* [Nizhyn](/wiki/Nizhyn "Nizhyn")
* [Ukrainka](/wiki/Ukrainka,_Kyiv_Oblast "Ukrainka, Kyiv Oblast")
* [Vasylkiv](/wiki/Vasylkiv "Vasylkiv")
* [Vyshhorod](/wiki/Vyshhorod "Vyshhorod")
* [Yahotyn](/wiki/Yahotyn "Yahotyn")

More than a dozen of *elektrychka* stops are within the city allowing residents of different neighborhoods to use the suburban trains.  

### Energy {#Energy}

[DTEK Kyiv Electric Networks](/w/index.php?title=DTEK_Kyiv_Electric_Networks&action=edit&redlink=1 "DTEK Kyiv Electric Networks (page does not exist)") \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%94%D0%A2%D0%95%D0%9A_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D1%96_%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B6%D1%96 "uk:ДТЕК Київські електромережі")\] (formerly Kyivenergo) is the electric power [distribution network operator](/wiki/Distribution_network_operator "Distribution network operator") for Kyiv, owned by oligarch [Rinat Akhmetov](/wiki/Rinat_Akhmetov "Rinat Akhmetov"). As of 2021^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kyiv&action=edit)^ it had:^[\[157\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/TEC-5%28low%29.jpg/220px-TEC-5%28low%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:TEC-5(low).jpg) CHP-5 (ТЕЦ-5) is the largest and most powerful [combined heat and power](/wiki/Cogeneration "Cogeneration") plant in Ukraine.

* 12,038 km of power transmission lines with a voltage of 0.4--110 kV
* 64 [substations](/wiki/Electrical_substation "Electrical substation") with a voltage of 35--110 kV
* 243 [switchgears](/wiki/Switchgear "Switchgear") and 3728 [transformer substations](/wiki/Transformer_substation "Transformer substation") at 10 kV

[Kyivteploenergo](/w/index.php?title=Kyivteploenergo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kyivteploenergo (page does not exist)") \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%BE "uk:Київтеплоенерго")\] operates a centralized heating system, which provides heating and hot water to customers through a network of pipes that distribute hot water from centralized heating plants to buildings throughout the city. It operates a 2700 km network, two of the largest [combined heat and power](/wiki/Cogeneration "Cogeneration") plants in Ukraine CHP-5 and CHP-6, as well as the only [waste incineration](/wiki/Waste_incineration "Waste incineration") plant [Energia (plant)](/w/index.php?title=Energia_(plant)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Energia (plant) (page does not exist)") \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4_%C2%AB%D0%95%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D1%96%D1%8F%C2%BB "uk:Завод «Енергія»")\] operating in Ukraine.

In line with the EU [Third Energy Package](/wiki/Third_Energy_Package "Third Energy Package"), since 2019 state energy policy abandoned the [Rotterdam plus](/wiki/Rotterdam_plus "Rotterdam plus") system and has required transmission system operator (TSO) and regional utilities unbundling in order to separate electricity distribution and retail electricity supply.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-161)^{#cite_ref-161}  

### Water and sanitation {#Water_and_sanitation}

The national government has delegated responsibility for water and sanitation services to local authorities.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-162)^ [Kyivvodokanal](/w/index.php?title=Kyivvodokanal&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kyivvodokanal (page does not exist)") \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%97%D0%B2%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB "uk:Київводоканал")\] is a [private joint-stock company](/wiki/Joint-stock_company#Ukraine "Joint-stock company") that provides such services to Kyiv. The length of water supply networks is 4231 km, of which 1798 km are dilapidated. The length of sewage networks is 2662 km, of which 830 km are dilapidated.{#cite_ref-162}

* [Olga of Kiev](/wiki/Olga_of_Kiev "Olga of Kiev") ( 900--969), a regent of [Kievan Rus'](/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27 "Kievan Rus'") for her son [Sviatoslav](/wiki/Sviatoslav_I "Sviatoslav I") from 945 until 960^[\[169\]](#cite_note-172)^{#cite_ref-172}
* Nicholas Pritzker, scion of the [Pritzker Family](/wiki/Pritzker_Family "Pritzker Family")
